==Awards and honors==
*The group were inducted into the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]] in 1998.<ref name="Flashback"/>
*The Eagles are four-time [[Country Music Association Award for Vocal Group of the Year]] nominees, being nominated in 1976, 1977, 2008 and 2009.<ref>{{cite web|title= Past Winners And Nominees |publisher= [[Country Music Association Awards]] |access-date= May 11, 2022 |url= https://cmaawards.com/past-winners-and-nominees/}}</ref>
*On December 7, 1999, the Recording Industry of America honored the group with the Best Selling Album of the Century for ''[[Their Greatest Hits (1971–1975)]].''<ref>{{cite news |title= Eagles hits album named best-selling of century |publisher= CNN |date= December 8, 1999 |url= http://archives.cnn.com/1999/SHOWBIZ/Music/12/08/eagles/ |access-date= October 27, 2007 |archive-date= August 16, 2011 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20110816155604/http://archives.cnn.com/1999/SHOWBIZ/Music/12/08/eagles/ |url-status= dead }}</ref>
*The Eagles were inducted into the [[Vocal Group Hall of Fame]] in 2001.<ref>{{cite web|title= 2001 Inductee |publisher= Vocal Group Hall of Fame |access-date= May 11, 2022 |url= http://vocalgroup.org/album_category/2001-inductee/?events=next}}</ref>
*The group ranked number 34 on ''[[Country Music Television]]'s 40 Greatest Men of Country Music'' in 2003.<ref>{{cite web|title= 40 Greatest Men of Country Music |publisher= [[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]] |url= http://www.cmt.com/cmt/shows/40greatestmen.list.jhtml |archive-date= June 2, 2003 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20030602074347/http://www.cmt.com/cmt/shows/40greatestmen.list.jhtml}}</ref>
*The group were chosen for the 2015 [[Kennedy Center Honors]] to be held on December 6 of that year, but postponed the award for a year because of Glenn Frey's poor health.<ref name="Kennedy"/> Frey died a month later.<ref name="Morton"/><ref name="TMZ"/>

===Grammy Awards===
The group has been nominated for 18 [[Grammy Award]]s, which resulted in 6 wins.<ref>{{cite web|title= Eagles |publisher= [[National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences]] |access-date= July 17, 2020 |url= https://www.grammy.com/grammys/artists/eagles}}</ref>

'''Flatland Cavalry''' is a [[country music|country]] and [[Americana (music)|Americana]] band from [[Lubbock, Texas]].<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/flatland-cavalry-mn0003425378/biography|title=Flatland Cavalry|publisher=Allmusic|accessdate=January 5, 2017}}</ref>  The band's original members were vocalist Cleto Cordero, drummer Jason Albers, bassist Jonathan Saenz, guitarist Reid Dillon, and violinist Laura Jane. Jane departed the band in July 2018 and was replaced by Wesley Hall.<ref name=":1">{{cite web | url=https://www.savingcountrymusic.com/fiddle-player-laura-jane-houle-leaves-flatland-cavalry/ | title=Fiddle Player Laura Jane Houle Leaves Flatland Cavalry | publisher=Saving Country Music | date=July 31, 2018 | accessdate=November 19, 2018}}</ref><ref name="koke">{{cite web | url=http://kokefm.com/flatland-cavalry-announce-homeland-insecurity/ | title=Flatland Cavalry Announce 'Homeland Insecurity' | publisher=KOKE FM | accessdate=19 November 2018}}</ref>

Flatland Cavalry was formed in 2012 by Cordero and Albers, who were college roommates in [[Midland, Texas|Midland]] and performed together before moving to Lubbock, where the rest of the members came together by 2014.<ref name="lo">{{cite web|url=http://lubbockonline.com/go/music/2015-05-07/flatland-cavalry-performing-cd-release-party-thursday-blue-light|title=Flatland Cavalry performing CD release party Thursday at the Blue Light |publisher=Lubbock Online|date=May 7, 2015|accessdate=January 5, 2017}}</ref><ref name="kcbd">{{cite web|url=http://www.kcbd.com/story/31672180/lubbock-band-flatland-cavalry-rises-to-no-2-on-itunes-country-chart|title=Lubbock band Flatland Cavalry rises to No. 2 on iTunes Country Chart|publisher=KCBD|date=April 7, 2016|accessdate=January 5, 2017}}</ref>  In May 2015, the band's debut [[extended play|EP]], titled ''Come May'', was released after a [[crowd-funding]] campaign was used to finance its production.<Ref name="lo"/>  On April 1, 2016, their first full-length album, ''Humble Folks'', was released<ref name="kcbd"/> to positive reviews and comparisons to the music of the [[Turnpike Troubadours]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lonestarmusicmagazine.com/8906-2/|title=Flatland Cavalry: "Humble Folks"|publisher=Lone Star Music Magazine|date=April 4, 2016|accessdate=January 5, 2017}}</ref>  ''Humble Folks'' peaked at number 17 on the Billboard Americana/Folk albums chart<ref name=":2">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/7327275/flatland-cavalry/chart?f=1071|title=Flatland Cavalry - Chart History (American/Folk albums)|publisher=Billboard|accessdate=January 5, 2017}}</ref> and number 38 on the Top Country Albums chart.<ref name=":3">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/7327275/flatland-cavalry/chart?f=320|title=Flatland Cavalry - Chart History (Top Country Albums)|publisher=Billboard|accessdate=January 5, 2017}}</ref>  The band's second studio album, ''Homeland Insecurity'', was released on January 18, 2019.<ref name="koke"/>

[[Kaitlin Butts]], who is married to Cordero and an accomplished musician in her own right, is a frequent collaborator with the band and a oft-seen part of their live shows. <ref>{{Cite web|title=Shots with the Band Featuring Kaitlin Butts & Cleto Cordero of Flatland Cavalry {{!}}|url=http://texasmusicpickers.com/shots-with-the-band-featuring-kaitlin-butts-cleto-cordero-of-flatland-cavalry/|access-date=2021-01-20|language=en-US}}</ref>

== Formation ==
The roots for the formation of Flatland Cavalry were first laid when Cleto Cordero and Jason Albers began playing at local venues while rooming together at [[Midland College]].<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=http://www.midlandlivingmagazine.com/2019/05/28/200570/flatland-cavalry-takes-texas-by-storm|title=Flatland Cavalry takes Texas by Storm {{!}} Midland Living|last=|first=|date=|website=Midland Living|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2019-10-30}}</ref><ref name=":0" /> The two had been jamming together since junior high but it was not until they moved to Lubbock in 2012 that the band began to take shape. It was here, while studying at [[Texas Tech University]], that the duo met Laura Jane at a house party. Jonathan Saenz and Reid Dillon joined the rest in 2014 and the band's lineup was complete.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":0" />

Cordero himself began playing the guitar at age 14 and wrote his first song by the time he was 17 years old for Lee High School's Rebel Lee Court Awards Ceremony.<ref name=":5" /> He writes most of the band's songs apart from playing the role of lead guitarist and singer with Jason Albers on drums, Jonathan Saenz on bass, Reid Dillon on guitar and Wesley Hall on fiddle. Hall took the place of Laura Jane when she parted ways with the band in 2018.<ref name=":1" /><ref name="koke" />

== Discography ==

=== EPs ===

==== ''Come May'' (2015) ====
The band released its first EP in 2015, gathering funds for its production via a crowdfunding platform.<ref name="lo" /> The band reached its goal of $5,000 in just eight days, a testament to the fan following they had already mustered through live performances.<ref name="lo" />

'''Track list'''<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=https://www.flatlandcavalry.com/listen|title=LISTEN|website=Flatland Cavalry|language=en-US|access-date=2019-10-30}}</ref>

# "Love Me in the Water"
# "Summertime Love"
# "Missing You"
# "Ain't Over You Yet"

# "Show Me Now Which Way To Go"

=== Albums ===

==== ''Humble Folks'' (2016) ====
It was the release of its debut EP followed by its first album, ''Humble Folks'', in 2016 that really got the ball rolling, with music insiders comparing Flatland to the likes of the [[Turnpike Troubadours]], lauding the band for its youthful blend of country, folk, Americana and rock. ''Humble Folks'' peaked at #38 on the Billboard Country Music Top 100 chart and #17 on the American/Folk Albums chart.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3" />

'''Track list'''<ref name=":6" />
# "One I Want"
# "A Good Memory"
# "February Snow"
# "Tall City Blues"
# "Coyote (The Ballad of Roy Johnson)"
# "Devil Off My Back"
# "Stompin' Grounds"
# "Goodbye Kiss"
# "A Life Where We Work Out" (feat. Kaitlin Butts)
# "Traveler's Song"
# "Humble Folks"

==== ''Homeland Insecurity'' (2019) ====
In 2018, Laura Jane left the band and was soon replaced by Wesley Hall on fiddle.<ref name=":1" /> With the new lineup in place, the quintet released their second album, ''Homeland Insecurity'', in 2019; three years after the release of their debut.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://eventseeker.com/artist/63269-flatland-cavalry|title=Flatland Cavalry - Artist Profile|last=|first=|date=|website=eventseeker.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2019-10-30}}</ref> In the time that lapsed between the two, the band toured extensively, honing their skill as musicians and drawing on their experiences to craft their sophomore work.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://sixshootercountry.com/2019/01/22/flatland-cavalry-homeland-insecurity-review/|title=Flatland Cavalry - Homeland Insecurity {{!}} Review|date=2019-01-22|website=Six Shooter Country|language=en-GB|access-date=2019-10-30}}</ref> As the band's primary songwriter, Cordero penned lyrics for ''Homeland Insecurity'' are markedly more sophisticated than his previous songs. The album was widely well-received and praised for its distinctive sound.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.texasmusicpickers.com/homeland-insecurity-by-flatland-cavalry-was-well-worth-the-wait/|title="Homeland Insecurity" by Flatland Cavalry was Well Worth the Wait|website=Texas Music Pickers|language=en-US|access-date=2019-10-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.savingcountrymusic.com/album-review-flatland-cavalrys-homeland-insecurity/|title=Album Review – Flatland Cavalry's "Homeland Insecurity"|first=|date=2019-01-23|website=Saving Country Music|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2019-10-30}}</ref>

====''Wandering Stars'' (2023)====

The Texan country-Americana band announced the release of their fourth studio album, “Wandering Star” on Oct, 27th 2023.<ref name=":7">{{Cite web |date=2023-11-01 |title=Flatland Cavalry Announces Fourth Studio LP: "Wandering Star" {{!}} TicketTaper Presale Codes, Concert Ticket, Tour Dates, Concert News |url=https://tickettaper.com/flatland-cavalry-announces-fourth-studio-lp-wandering-star/ |access-date=2023-11-01 |website=tickettaper.com |language=en-US}}</ref> The album, is their first release on Interscope Records, which follows their successful 2022 EP, “Songs To Keep You Warm”. “Wandering Star” consists of 13 solo tracks and one collaborative track featuring Kaitlin Butts.<ref name=":7" />

'''Fleet Foxes''' are an American [[indie folk]] band formed in [[Seattle]], Washington, in 2006. The band currently consists of [[Robin Pecknold]] (vocals, guitar), Skyler Skjelset (guitar, mandolin, backing vocals), Casey Wescott (keyboards, mandolin, backing vocals), [[Christian Wargo]] (bass, guitar, backing vocals), and Morgan Henderson (upright bass, guitar, woodwinds, violin, percussion, saxophone). Founding members Pecknold and Skjelset have been the only constants through the group's history, with the former serving as leader and principal songwriter.

The band came to prominence in 2008 with the release of their second EP ''[[Sun Giant]]'' and their [[Fleet Foxes (album)|eponymous debut album]] on [[Sub Pop]], both of which met with widespread critical acclaim. Their sophomore album ''[[Helplessness Blues]]'' (2011) earned further praise and became their greatest commercial success to date, reaching number 4 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]]. Following a three-year break, Fleet Foxes reconvened in 2016 to record their third album ''[[Crack-Up (album)|Crack-Up]]'', which was released the following year on [[Nonesuch Records]]. This was followed by 2020's ''[[Shore (album)|Shore]]'', a ''de facto'' Pecknold solo album made without the involvement of his bandmates and released through the [[Anti- (record label)|Anti-]] label.

Though the group has experienced limited commercial success, their work has been consistently lauded by [[music critics]], who have praised their lyricism and production style and often noted the band's use of refined instrumentation and vocal harmonies. The band's debut album was ranked by ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' among the best of the decade and was also included in the book ''[[1001 Albums You Must Hear Before You Die]]''. The band has been nominated for two [[Grammy Awards]], the first for [[Grammy Award for Best Folk Album|Best Folk Album]] in 2012 for ''Helplessness Blues'' and the second for [[Grammy Award for Best Alternative Music Album|Best Alternative Music Album]] in 2022 for ''Shore''.

==History==

===Formation and early years (2005–06)===
[[Robin Pecknold]] and Skyler Skjelset both attended [[Lake Washington High School]] in [[Kirkland, Washington|Kirkland]], a suburb of Seattle, and soon became close friends. Pecknold and Skjelset bonded over an appreciation of [[Bob Dylan]] and [[Neil Young]] and began making music together.<ref name=RSHarmony>{{cite magazine |last=Scaggs |first=Austin |title=Fleet Foxes' Perfect Harmony |magazine=Rolling Stone |date=November 13, 2008 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/24012632/fleet_foxes_perfect_harmony |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081106121640/http://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/24012632/fleet_foxes_perfect_harmony |url-status=dead |archive-date=November 6, 2008 |access-date=December 1, 2008}}</ref> Their parents influenced their musical tastes early on&mdash;Skjelset's mother Peggi was a keen listener to both Dylan and [[Hank Williams]] while Pecknold's father Greg was a member of The Fathoms, a local 1960s soul group.<ref name=Indep1>{{cite news |last=James |first=McNair |title=On the hunt for meaning with Seattle band Fleet Foxes |work=[[The Independent]] |date=June 13, 2008 |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/on-the-hunt-for-meaning-with-seattle-band-fleet-foxes-846150.html |access-date=December 1, 2008}}</ref> The two shared an interest in the music of Dylan and [[Brian Wilson]]. Pecknold played bass for Seattle's [[Dolour]] on a US tour in 2005, shortly before forming the first incarnation of Fleet Foxes.

Originally going by the name "The Pineapples", a name clash with another local band prompted a change and Pecknold decided upon "Fleet Foxes", suggesting that it was "evocative of some weird English activity like fox hunting".<ref name=Indep1/> Pecknold took up the role of principal songwriter, both singing and playing guitar, while Skjelset played lead guitar.<ref>[http://www.seattlemag.com/article/power-25-fleet-foxes-expand-seattle-sound-1 "Fleet Foxes Expand Seattle Sound"], ''Seattle'' magazine</ref> The original lineup was filled out by Casey Wescott on keyboards and backing vocals, Bryn Lumsden on bass and Nicholas Peterson on drums and backing vocals.

Pecknold's late-sixties pop style caught the attention of the Seattle producer [[Phil Ek]] and he helped them record their first demo in 2006, the self-released ''[[Fleet Foxes (EP)|Fleet Foxes]]'' EP.<ref name=ST1>{{cite web |last=Scanlon |first=Tom |title=Fleet Foxes sing it their way |work=Seattle Times |date=September 22, 2006 |url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/musicnightlife/2003269559_nite22.html |access-date=December 3, 2008}}</ref> Ek was impressed with the band's songwriting, and on hearing Pecknold for the first time, noted, "It was obvious he had talent coming out of his ass."<ref name=RSHarmony/> By late 2006 the Seattle press began to take notice of the band; Tom Scanlon of the ''[[Seattle Times]]'' stated that he was impressed with the band's lyrics and musical maturity.<ref name=ST1/> By the end of the year, Lumsden had been replaced on bass by Craig Curran, who would also handle many of the band's vocal harmonies.

With growing popularity on the local circuit, the band set about making their first album in early 2007, spending time in the studio with producer Ek in addition to recording material at home.  However, funds for recording were tight, so the band members cobbled together what funds they had, which limited the time they had in the studio, and so the majority of the tracks were recorded in various band members' apartments, other spaces, or the basement of Pecknold's parents' house.<ref name=RSHarmony/>

===''Sun Giant'' and ''Fleet Foxes'' (2007–08)===
[[File:Fleetfoxes08.jpg|thumb|left|260px|Fleet Foxes performing in [[Copenhagen]], 2008.]]
Fleet Foxes were becoming increasingly popular and by late 2007, they had attracted over a quarter of a million song plays over two months on their [[Myspace]] site.<ref name="Lester">{{cite web |last=Lester |first=Paul |title=No 272: Fleet Foxes |work=The Guardian |date=February 11, 2008 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2008/feb/11/popandrock1 |access-date=December 3, 2008}}</ref> Although the band had not released any of their recordings, they benefited from [[word of mouth]] exposure and their success soon translated into a record deal, signing with [[Warner Music Group|Warner Music]] subsidiary record label [[Sub Pop]] on January 18, 2008.<ref name="Lester"/> The band's frontman, Robin Pecknold, attributes much of their success and popularity to illegal [[file sharing]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Youngs |first=Ian |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/8097324.stm |title=Entertainment &#124; Bands 'better because of piracy' |work=BBC News |date=June 12, 2009|access-date=July 5, 2010}}</ref>

The band tracked their second EP, ''[[Sun Giant]]'', at [[Bear Creek Studio]] and performed overdubs and mixed at Seattle's [[Avast! Recording Co.]], around the same time in preparation for upcoming tours.<ref>{{cite web |last=Pecknold |first=Aja |title=It's Official: Fleet Foxes Sign with Sub Pop |work=[[Seattle Weekly]] |date=January 18, 2008 |url=http://blogs.seattleweekly.com/reverb/2008/01/its_official_fleet_foxes_sign.php |access-date=December 3, 2008 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081207005307/http://blogs.seattleweekly.com/reverb/2008/01/its_official_fleet_foxes_sign.php |archive-date=December 7, 2008 }}</ref> Fleet Foxes began their spring tour with another [[Pacific Northwest|Northwest]] band [[Blitzen Trapper]] on February 28, 2008.<ref name="Billboard">{{cite magazine | url = http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1046777/seattles-fleet-foxes-sign-with-sub-pop | title = Billboard.com on Fleet Foxes | magazine = [[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | first = Megan | last = Seling | access-date = March 2, 2008 }}</ref> Before the recording of the EP, bassist Curran was replaced by [[Christian Wargo]], whose voice, like that of his predecessor, would become an important part of the band's harmony blend. The band's performances, first at the [[SXSW]] festival in March 2008, and then the [[Sasquatch!]] festival in May 2008, moved the band into the public consciousness, notably attracting attention from the European press for the first time.<ref name=Indep1/>

''Sun Giant'' was released internationally on April 8, 2008, and the group's brand of folk, rock and pop, marked by their use of vocal harmonies, was well received by the press.<ref>{{cite web |last=Phares |first=Heather |title=Sun Giant EP Review |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=r1340554|pure_url=yes}} |access-date=December 3, 2008}}</ref> Despite the warm critical reception, the group said that the EP did not represent their full ambitions, serving merely as a CD to sell while on tour.<ref>{{cite news |last=Gill |first=Andy |title=Album: Fleet Foxes, Sun Giant (Bella Union) |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |date=April 25, 2008 |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/reviews/album-fleet-foxes-sun-giant-bella-union-815026.html |access-date=December 3, 2008}}</ref> In May 2008, the band chose to extend their North American and European tour until September in support of their forthcoming album. At this time [[Josh Tillman]] replaced Peterson on drums and backing vocals.<ref>{{cite web |last=Mason-Campbell |first=Nilina |title=Fleet Foxes Add New Member, More Tour Dates |publisher=[[Pitchfork Media]] |date=May 2, 2008 |url=http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/article/news/50373-fleet-foxes-add-new-member-more-tour-dates |access-date=December 3, 2008 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080505053228/http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/article/news/50373-fleet-foxes-add-new-member-more-tour-dates |archive-date=May 5, 2008 }}</ref> Their first full-length album, ''[[Fleet Foxes (album)|Fleet Foxes]]'', was released shortly afterwards on June 3, 2008.<ref>{{cite web |last=Phares |first=Heather |title=Fleet Foxes Review |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=r1384411|pure_url=yes}} |access-date=December 3, 2008}}</ref> The album achieved similar critical success as the previous EP. ''Fleet Foxes'' received four out of five stars from ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', which compared it to the likes of the [[Beach Boys]], [[Animal Collective]], and [[Crosby, Stills & Nash]],<ref>{{cite magazine |last=Hermes |first=Will |title=Fleet Foxes |magazine=Rolling Stone |date=June 12, 2008 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/reviews/album/20949207/review/20961620/fleet_foxes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080529063312/http://www.rollingstone.com/reviews/album/20949207/review/20961620/fleet_foxes |url-status=dead |archive-date=May 29, 2008 |access-date=November 27, 2008}}</ref> and a 9.0 out of 10 in a review by [[Pitchfork Media]], sharing the website's album of the year rank with the ''Sun Giant'' EP.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/article/record_review/51076-fleet-foxes | title = Fleet Foxes LP Review | publisher = [[Pitchfork Media]] | first = Stephen M. | last = Deusner | access-date = June 6, 2008 | url-status = dead | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20080608232603/http://www.pitchforkmedia.com/article/record_review/51076-fleet-foxes | archive-date = June 8, 2008}}</ref> ''[[The Guardian]]'' was particularly complimentary, awarding the album five stars and declaring it "a landmark in American music — an instant classic".<ref>{{cite web | last=Simpson |first=Dave |title = Fleet Foxes, Fleet Foxes |date = May 30, 2008 |work = The Guardian |url = http://music.guardian.co.uk/folk/reviews/story/0,,2282853,00.html |access-date = December 3, 2008}}</ref> On June 24, 2008, ''Fleet Foxes'' went to No.&nbsp;1 on the [[College Music Journal|CMJ]] Radio 200 Chart.<ref>{{cite web |last=Shaer |first=Matthew |title=Let the light in: With their self-titled debut, Fleet Foxes are putting a new shine on folk music |work=The Boston Globe |date=July 11, 2008 |url=http://www.boston.com/ae/music/articles/2008/07/11/let_the_light_in/ |access-date=November 27, 2008}}</ref> The album achieved an average rating of 87/100 from 30 critic reviews on the aggregator website [[Metacritic]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Fleet Foxes by Fleet Foxes |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |date=December 3, 2008 |url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/artists/fleetfoxes/fleetfoxes?q=fleet%20foxes |access-date=December 3, 2008 |archive-date=December 16, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081216072315/http://www.metacritic.com/music/artists/fleetfoxes/fleetfoxes?q=fleet%20foxes |url-status=dead }}</ref>

While the group enjoyed moderate success in the United States, ''Fleet Foxes'' was better received in Europe, selling over 200,000 copies in the five months following its release.<ref name=Graun1>{{cite web |last=Swash |first=Rosie |title=Fleet Foxes' coup signals folk revival |work=The Guardian |date=November 17, 2008 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2008/nov/17/folk-revival-fleet-foxes |access-date=December 3, 2008}}</ref> The sales were matched with critical plaudits and their debut album won ''[[Uncut (magazine)|Uncut's]]'' first ever Music Award 2008 prize.<ref>{{cite web |title=Uncut Music Award winner revealed |work=[[Uncut (magazine)|Uncut]] |url=http://www.uncut.co.uk/news/uncut/news/12440/ |access-date=December 3, 2008 |archive-date=January 7, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090107104154/http://www.uncut.co.uk/news/uncut/news/12440/ |url-status=dead }}</ref> ''Uncut'''s editor, Allan Jones, said the album "showed impeccable musicianship, and although you could trace its antecedents, it sounded totally unique. Fleet Foxes was just a glorious debut." The band sold out music venues for their tours of Australia, New Zealand and the United Kingdom, reaffirming their growing popularity.<ref name=Graun1/><ref name=Indy1>Sauma, Luiza (December 7, 2008). [https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/fleet-foxes-are-a-hairy-bunch-of-young-folkrockers-inventing-a-new-sound-of-seattle-1052035.html "Fleet Foxes: Are a hairy bunch of young folk-rockers inventing a new sound of Seattle?"], ''[[The Independent]]''. Retrieved on January 19, 2009.</ref>

At the end of 2008, ''Fleet Foxes'' was rated album of the year by ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'''s Critic's Choice and in [[Metacritic]]'s end of year best album round-up it appeared in 17 lists, topping six of them. Furthermore, it had sold over 408,000 copies in North America and over 100,000 copies in the United Kingdom, making it the first [[gold album|gold]] certificate record for UK label [[Bella Union]].<ref>Paine, Andre (December 23, 2008). [http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/266062/fleet-foxes-go-gold-in-united-kingdom "Fleet Foxes Go Gold In United Kingdom"]. ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]''. Retrieved on January 29, 2009.</ref> Their growing profile enabled the band to make televised appearances, playing on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' in January 2009. In 2009, they toured in Europe to favorable reviews; the Dutch newspaper ''[[De Volkskrant]]'' said their show in [[Paradiso (Amsterdam)|Paradiso]] induced goosebumps.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kippenvel bij optreden Fleet Foxes in Paradiso|last = Kamer|first=Gijsbert |work=[[De Volkskrant]]|date=July 2, 2009|url=https://www.volkskrant.nl/recensies/kippenvel-bij-optreden-fleet-foxes-in-paradiso~a339331/|access-date=September 15, 2017}}</ref> In 2008 and 2009, the band played globally ending the tour in September with a final European leg.

===''Helplessness Blues'' (2009–12)===
{{main|Helplessness Blues}}
[[File:Fleet Foxes Coachella.jpg|thumb|right|260px|Fleet Foxes performing at the [[Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival|2009 Coachella Festival]].]]
Pecknold said that he would have liked the album to be released in 2009; however, the band's touring schedule delayed rehearsals of the new songs until February 2009. These sessions took place in a rented house outside Seattle, but were mostly scrapped, losing the band $60,000 of their own money. Further delays ensued because the drummer, Tillman, was scheduled to play a solo tour in Europe and North America throughout the 2009–10 winter. Pecknold later sent some demos to producer Phil Ek and expressed the hope that the second LP would emerge in late 2010.

In December 2009, Pecknold said he wanted the new LP to sound "less poppy, less upbeat and more groove-based". He referenced the 12-string guitar sound from [[Roy Harper (singer)|Roy Harper]]'s folk album ''[[Stormcock (album)|Stormcock]]'', saying, "That will be the primary sonic distancing from the last record." He wanted the band to record very quickly, with "vocal takes in one go, so even if there are fuck-ups, I want them to be on there. I want there to be guitar mistakes. I want there to be not totally flawless vocals. I want to record it and have that kind of cohesive sound. [[Van Morrison]]'s ''[[Astral Weeks]]'', to me, is the best-sounding album because it sounds like there were only six hours in the universe for that album to be recorded in. So I want it to have that feeling."<ref>{{cite news |last=Michaels |first=Sean |title=Fleet Foxes Recording 'Pretty Boring' Second Album |newspaper=The Guardian |date=December 7, 2009 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2009/dec/07/fleet-foxes-second-album |access-date=December 14, 2013 |location=London}}</ref> The band eventually began recording in April 2010 in various locations (including West Hurley, New York) under the label Reciprocal Recording and decided to scrap the earlier idea of a fast recording (though according to the band many of the initial vocals were done in one take). The album features a new six-piece band line up, with the addition of the former [[The Blood Brothers (band)|Blood Brothers]] bassist [[Morgan Henderson]] on upright bass and woodwind instruments.<ref>Hay, Travis [http://www.guerrillacandy.com/2011/04/17/fleet-foxes-add-a-blood-brother-for-sixth-member/ "Fleet Foxes add a Blood Brother for sixth member"] ''Guerilla Candy'', April 17, 2011</ref>

The album, ''[[Helplessness Blues]]'', was released on May 3, 2011, with a cover illustrated by the [[Seattle]] artist Toby Liebowitz and painted by Christopher Alderson.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.subpop.com/channel/blog/fleet_foxes_announce_second_album_helplessness_blues_pre_order_now |author=Alissa |title=Fleet Foxes Announce Second Album, Helplessness Bblues, Pre-Order Now |publisher=Sub Pop Records |date=January 31, 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130115154024/http://www.subpop.com/channel/blog/fleet_foxes_announce_second_album_helplessness_blues_pre_order_now |archive-date=January 15, 2013 }}</ref> The title track was released via free download on January 31, 2011, and the album's fourth track, "Battery Kinzie", was premiered in the UK on [[Zane Lowe]]'s radio show on March 22, 2011. The [[Sub Pop]] record label released a downloadable music video of the track "Grown Ocean", with footage of the album's recording, on its website in support of the album. A 12" vinyl double A-side single of "Helplessness Blues" and "Grown Ocean" was released for Record Store Day on April 16, 2011. On November 1, 2011, Pecknold's brother, Sean Pecknold, released the official music video for "The Shrine / An Argument".<ref>{{cite web |last=Murray |first=Robin |title=Watch: Fleet Foxes - The Shrine / An Argument |work=[[Clash (magazine)|Clash]] |date=October 25, 2011 |url=http://www.clashmusic.com/news/watch-fleet-foxes-the-shrine-an-argument |access-date=October 25, 2011}}</ref>

''Helplessness Blues'' was nominated as [[Best Folk Album]] at the 2012 [[Grammy]] Awards, held February 12, 2012.

===Departure of Tillman and hiatus (2012–2016)===
On January 18, 2012, after the band had finished touring for the album, drummer Tillman announced that he had left the band.<ref>Pelly, Jenn [http://pitchfork.com/news/45163-j-tillman-leaves-fleet-foxes-other-members-form-new-band-poor-moon/ "J. Tillman Leaves Fleet Foxes, Other Members Form New Band Poor Moon"] ''[[Pitchfork Media|Pitchfork]]'', January 19, 2012</ref> He would go on to reinvent himself and record several albums as [[Father John Misty]], notable for his ironic sense of humor in lyrics and media as well as often criticizing both the record industry and society in interviews and on stage. Pecknold would later reflect on Tillman's departure during a [[r/IAmA|Reddit AMA]] in October 2020:

<blockquote>[Tillman] "quit" the band after recording drums for ''Helplessness'', got into narcotics and made his first [Father John Misty] album while I was making ''Helplessness'' in Seattle. Then Sub Pop offered to put out his album, but only if he delayed it for a year or so and toured ''Helplessness'' with us. Which we all weakly agreed to going through with, but it quickly became obvious he'd rather have just been doing that project instead, and I would have rathered that as well. So that tour I had to endure being around a lot of substance abuse, sabotaged shows, just general ill treatment, shit-talking, all while paying him for songs he didn't have anything to do with. It sucked!<ref name="RedditAMA">{{cite web|url=https://www.reddit.com/r/indieheads/comments/j7j37d/im_robin_pecknold_of_fleet_foxes_ask_me_anything/|title=I'm Robin Pecknold of Fleet Foxes - Ask me anything! |work=[[Reddit]]|date=October 8, 2020 |access-date=October 9, 2020}}</ref></blockquote>

On June 15, 2013, an image of a home recording set-up—including a laptop computer, microphone and guitar—was posted on the Fleet Foxes Facebook page with the caption "Step one."<ref name=laptop>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10151734930243408&set=a.264432423407.179524.24709128407|title=Step One|publisher=Fleet Foxes|access-date=July 11, 2013|author=Fleet Foxes}}</ref> On June 16, 2013, an image of a broken mandolin with the caption "Step two" was posted.<ref name=mandolin>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10151737866113408&set=a.264432423407.179524.24709128407|publisher=Fleet Foxes|title=Step One|access-date=July 11, 2013|author=Fleet Foxes}}</ref> These images were later deleted, but led to speculation that the group was working on a new project, possibly a third studio album.<ref name=laptop /><ref name=mandolin /> On April 23, 2014, Robin Pecknold posted to the band's Facebook page that he had moved to New York to get his undergraduate degree at the [[Columbia University School of General Studies]], a liberal arts college of [[Columbia University]] in [[New York City]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Minsker|first1=Evan|title=Robin Pecknold Explains Fleet Foxes Hiatus|url=http://pitchfork.com/news/54914-robin-pecknold-explains-fleet-foxes-hiatus/|access-date=May 28, 2015|work=Pitchfork|date=April 23, 2014}}</ref>

===''Crack-Up'' (2016–2018)===
On May 18, 2016, while answering fan questions on his Instagram account, Pecknold confirmed that Fleet Foxes were working on new material with drummer and frequent collaborator [[Neal Morgan]], best known for his work with [[Joanna Newsom]] and [[Bill Callahan (musician)|Bill Callahan]]. Describing Morgan as a "full Fox", Pecknold also admitted he "had to up my songwriting game for homeboy." However, when Pecknold posted a photo of the band minus Morgan on Instagram, he clarified that Morgan was one of three drummers involved in the new album, and that for the time being Fleet Foxes would consist of Pecknold, Skjelset, Wescott, Wargo, and Henderson as a "five-piece 'core band'", but they would still use a drummer for live performances and additional musicians for certain shows.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BQmPr_LjFr2|title=Shawn Brackbill|last=Pecknold|first=Robin|publisher=Instagram|date=February 17, 2017|access-date=June 8, 2017}}</ref> Pecknold also said that the new material would be "a different vibe" compared to Fleet Foxes' previous output.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://instagram.com/p/BFiBvIRr-kq/|title=No-Self-y|last=Pecknold|first=Robin|publisher=Instagram|date=May 18, 2016|access-date=June 8, 2017}}</ref> On November 14, 2016, the band confirmed (via their Facebook account) that their new album was nearly complete.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/24709128407/photos/a.10150796955053408.474915.24709128407/10154762552673408/?type=3&comment_id=10154762556993408&reply_comment_id=10154762560213408&comment_tracking=%7B%22tn%22:%22R9%22%7D|title=Fleet Foxes - Fleet Foxes updated their cover photo. |website=Facebook.com|access-date=November 22, 2016}}</ref>

On December 25, 2016, Pecknold posted a photo on his Instagram account which showed four albums in the Fleet Foxes' queue in his iTunes library: the first studio album ''Fleet Foxes''; the ''Sun Giant'' EP; the second studio album ''Helplessness Blues''; and an unknown third album entitled ''Ylajali''.<ref name="stereogum.com">{{cite web |url=http://www.stereogum.com/1917626/fleet-foxes-announce-lp3-ylajali-cover-art-new-label/news/|title=Fleet Foxes Announce LP3 Ylajali, Cover Art, New Label?|last=Rettig|first=James|publisher=Stereogum|date=December 25, 2016|access-date=December 25, 2016}}</ref> This led to speculation that the band's third album would: 1) be named after a character from [[Knut Hamsun]]'s novel ''[[Hunger (Hamsun novel)|Hunger]]''; 2) contain a photo from Japanese photographer [[Hiroshi Hamaya]] as the cover art; and 3) be released through [[Nonesuch Records]], since the label's logo can be seen on the album cover.<ref name="stereogum.com"/>

In an email newsletter on January 1, 2017, production company [[Mason Jar Music]] confirmed that Fleet Foxes was working on a new album, since they contributed to the production.<ref>{{Cite news|title=New Fleet Foxes Album|date=January 1, 2017|work=Mason Jar Music Newsletter|via=Email}}</ref> The album was called ''Crack-Up'', after an [[F. Scott Fitzgerald]] [[The Crack-Up|essay of the same name]]. The album is a concept album and was recorded at [[Electric Lady Studios]] and Sear Sound in New York City.

On March 7, 2017, Fleet Foxes announced their third studio album, ''[[Crack-Up (album)|Crack-Up]]'', released on June 16, 2017, via [[Nonesuch Records]], a new label for the band. The lead single, "Third of May / Ōdaigahara", was released the same day.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/fleet-foxes-announce-new-record-crack-up-us-tour-w470737|title=Fleet Foxes Preview First LP in Six Years With Epic New Song|last=Leight|first=Elias|publisher=Rolling Stone|date=March 7, 2017|access-date=March 7, 2017}}</ref> On April 4, 2017, the band posted the album trailer for the new album on YouTube. The trailer briefly presents various songs from the album and shows some images while they were recording them. The video was made by Sean Pecknold, Robin's brother.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uE_xsML2-uw| archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211117/uE_xsML2-uw| archive-date=November 17, 2021 | url-status=live|title=Fleet Foxes - Crack-Up (Album Trailer)|publisher=YouTube|date=April 4, 2017|access-date=April 4, 2017}}{{cbignore}}</ref>

On May 15, 2017, Fleet Foxes made their live return at the Wilma Theatre in Missoula, in which they performed nine songs from ''Crack-Up'' along with a selection of older material and a cover of "[[Morning of My Life|In the Morning]]" by [[Bee Gees]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://missoulian.com/entertainment/fleet-foxes-make-bracing-return-to-live-performance-at-missoula/article_cc2d7f0e-6fc5-5696-be63-62b66a5ecbcb.html|title=Fleet Foxes make bracing return to live performance at Missoula concert|last=Walsh|first=Cory|publisher=Missoulian|date=May 16, 2017|access-date=June 8, 2017}}</ref> The band's live line-up included Matt Barrick of [[The Walkmen]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wweek.com/music/2017/05/19/fleet-foxes-make-a-tentative-comeback-at-crystal-ballroom/|title=Fleet Foxes Make a Tentative Comeback at Crystal Ballroom|last=Singer|first=Matthew|publisher=Willamette Week|date=May 19, 2017|access-date=June 8, 2017}}</ref> who was also the most heavily featured of the three guest drummers who contributed to ''Crack-Up''. Barrick did not become an official member.  The new album also included the sounds of a brass quartet called The Westerlies.

On October 10, 2017, the band announced the release of a new EP, entitled ''The Electric Lady Session'', for [[Black Friday (shopping)|Black Friday]] [[Record Store Day]] 2017. The EP was released on November 24 of that year, and is a collection of live performances of four songs from ''Crack-Up'', originally recorded for their session at [[Fordham University]]'s radio station [[WFUV]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://pitchfork.com/news/fleet-foxes-announce-record-store-days-black-friday-vinyl-10/ |title=Fleet Foxes Announce Record Store Day's Black Friday Vinyl 10 |work=Pitchfork |date=October 10, 2017 |access-date=October 27, 2017 |author=Sodomsky, Sam}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://recordstoreday.com/NewsItem/7126 |title=FLEET FOXES BLACK FRIDAY 10 |work=RecordStoreDay.com |date=October 10, 2017 |access-date=October 27, 2017 |author=Record Store Day}}</ref> For [[Record Store Day]] 2018, the band released another EP, entitled "Crack Up (Choral Version)"/"In The Morning (Live in Switzerland)", in collaboration with the Icelandic female choir, Graduale Nobili.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.recordstoreday.com/SpecialRelease/10096 |title=FLEET FOXES "Crack Up (Choral Version)"/"In The Morning (Live in Switzerland)" |website=RecordStoreDay.com |date=April 21, 2018 |access-date=April 25, 2018 |author=Record Store Day}}</ref>

===''Shore'' (2019–present)===
Work began on a fourth studio album in late 2018, not long after the Crack-Up tour finished. On December 31, 2018, Pecknold teased several new demos online for an upcoming new album.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://consequence.net/2019/01/robin-pecknold-previews-new-fleet-foxes-album/|title=Robin Pecknold previews new Fleet Foxes album|website=Consequence.net|date=January 2, 2019}}</ref>

Recording began in September 2019 at Long Pond Studios in [[Hudson, New York]], and continued at other studios including [[Electro-Vox Recording Studios]] in Los Angeles. Pecknold collaborated closely with recording engineer Beatriz Artola during the recording process. Upon the outset of the [[COVID-19 pandemic]], Pecknold moved to [[New York City]] to be able to continue working with Artola. At this point, the majority of the music of the album was well-conceptualized, but the lyrics eluded Pecknold. He eventually developed the lyrics in part over the course of long drives in the New York countryside, and worked to finish the album in July and August 2020. Due to a desire to release the album quickly, Pecknold did not enlist the help of bandmates Skjelset, Wescott, Wargo, or Henderson.<ref name="RS Feature">{{Cite magazine |last1=Vozick-Levinson |first1=Simon |last2=Vozick-Levinson |first2=Simon |date=September 22, 2020 |title=Robin Pecknold's Season of Rebirth |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/fleet-foxes-shore-robin-pecknold-interview-1064060/ |access-date=September 22, 2020 |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]}}</ref>

The album was announced in September 2020; titled ''[[Shore (album)|Shore]]'', it was released on September 22.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.stereogum.com/2098765/fleet-foxes-shore-new-release-posters/news/|title=Fleet Foxes Posters Tease New Release On Tuesday|website=Stereogum.com|date=September 20, 2020|access-date=September 25, 2020}}</ref> The album received universal acclaim, scoring 87/100 on Metacritic, and was listed among the best albums of the year by numerous publications.<ref name="MC">{{Cite web |date=September 22, 2020 |title=Shore by Fleet Foxes Reviews and Tracks|url=https://www.metacritic.com/music/shore/fleet-foxes |access-date=December 8, 2020 |website=[[Metacritic]]}}</ref> It is nominated for [[Grammy Award for Best Alternative Music Album|Best Alternative Music Album]] at the [[64th Annual Grammy Awards]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/news/2022-grammys-complete-winners-nominees-nominations-list|title=2022 GRAMMYs Awards Show: Complete Nominations List |website=Grammys.com|date=November 23, 2021|access-date=November 23, 2021}}</ref>

On December 6, 2021, Fleet Foxes announced the release of a new [[live album]] entitled ''[[A Very Lonely Solstice]]''. The album was released digitally on December 10, 2021. Vinyl and CD releases are scheduled for release in spring 2022 through Anti-.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Hussey |first=Allison |date=December 6, 2021 |title=Fleet Foxes Announce ''A Very Lonely Solstice'' Live Album |url=https://pitchfork.com/news/fleet-foxes-announce-a-very-lonely-solstice-live-album/ |access-date=December 7, 2021 |website=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]}}</ref> ''A Very Lonely Solstice'' is a recording of a virtual, pre-recorded video concert performance that was [[Livestreaming|livestreamed]] at 9pm ET on December 21, 2020, coinciding with the [[winter solstice]]. The concert featured Pecknold performing an acoustic solo set inside the [[St. Ann & the Holy Trinity Church]] in Brooklyn.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Moreland |first=Quinn |date=December 1, 2020 |title=Fleet Foxes Announce A Very Lonely Solstice Livestream |url=https://pitchfork.com/news/fleet-foxes-announce-a-very-lonely-solstice-livestream/ |access-date=March 9, 2021 |website=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Bruce |first=Jasper |date=December 3, 2020 |title=Fleet Foxes announce 'A Very Lonely Solstice' livestream show |url=https://www.nme.com/news/music/fleet-foxes-announce-a-very-lonely-solstice-livestream-show-2830402 |access-date=March 8, 2021 |website=[[NME]]}}</ref> The album features performances of songs from ''Shore'' and older Fleet Foxes songs, as well as cover versions of two tracks.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Empire |first=Kitty |author-link=Kitty Empire |date=December 27, 2019 |title=Fleet Foxes: A Very Lonely Solstice live stream review – all is balm |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2020/dec/27/fleet-foxes-a-very-lonely-solstice-live-stream-review-all-is-balm |access-date=March 9, 2021 |website=[[The Observer]]}}</ref>
