'''Kristian Merrill Bush'''<!--middle name per BMI listings--> (born March 14, 1970) is an American singer, songwriter, and record producer. Bush is one half of the [[country music]] duo [[Sugarland]] with [[Jennifer Nettles]], and was a member of the [[folk rock]] duo [[Billy Pilgrim (band)|Billy Pilgrim]] with [[Andrew Hyra]]. In addition to his work in these two groups, Bush released one solo album, ''[[Southern Gravity]]'', via [[Streamsound Records]] in 2015, and four solo albums via Big Machine Records, 52 ATL x BNA, 52 | In The Key Of Summer, 52 | New Blue, and 52 | This Year in 2022 and 2023. In 2023 Bush also released an EP titled Drink Happy Thoughts on his own label Songs Of The Architect.

==Early life==
Kristian Bush was born in [[Knoxville, Tennessee]]. Bush was raised outside of Knoxville in [[Sevierville, Tennessee]], a small town at the base of the [[Smoky Mountains]] that was also the hometown of [[Dolly Parton]].<ref name="Emory Magazine">{{cite web|last=Parvin|first=Paige P.|title=Down in Sugarland| work= Emory Magazine|url= http://www.emory.edu/EMORY_MAGAZINE/2008/spring/sugarland.html|publisher=[[Emory University]]|access-date=October 27, 2014}}</ref> He is the great grandson of A.J. Bush, founder of [[Bush Brothers and Company]]; it was expected for him to run a cannery.<ref name="The Boot Bush Bros & Co.">{{cite web|last=Darden|first=Beville|title=Sugarland's Kristian Bush Talks 'Secret' Family Feud|url=http://www.theboot.com/2009/07/29/sugarlands-kristian-bush-talks-secret-family-business/|website= Theboot.com|access-date=October 27, 2014}}</ref><ref name="TED">{{Cite web |url=https://www.ted.com/talks/kristian_bush_when_you_can_t_do_what_you_do_anymore_then_what |title=Bush: When You Can't Do What You Do Anymore, Then What? |date=2019-06-10 |access-date=2024-02-20 |website=[[TED (conference)|TED Conferences]] |last=Bush |first=Kristian}}</ref> He was exposed to instruments from an early age, and picked up his first violin at age 4. During these early years, Bush, alongside younger brother Brandon, made his musical debut at the local Bush Beans Jamboree performing as Parton's opening act.<ref>{{cite web|last=Haynes|first=Beth|title=HomeGrown: Kristian and Brandon Bush, Sugarland|url=http://www.wbir.com/news/article/218352/2/HomeGrown-Kristian-and-Brandon-Bush-Sugarland|archive-url=https://archive.today/20141027140745/http://www.wbir.com/news/article/218352/2/HomeGrown-Kristian-and-Brandon-Bush-Sugarland|url-status=dead|archive-date=October 27, 2014|work=WBIR.com|access-date=October 27, 2014}}</ref> His grandparents made a "weird deal" when he was 12 and lost the Bush Brothers company, a deal they were ultimately bitter about, but it allowed Bush to grow up and be whatever he wanted.<ref name="TED"/>

Throughout childhood, Bush was enrolled in violin lessons and classically trained under the [[Suzuki method]] at the [[University of Tennessee]].<ref name="Emory Magazine" />  The family eventually relocated to Knoxville and by age 11, Bush agreed to play one season in the Knoxville Youth Symphony, before earning the right to lay the violin down for good and start learning the guitar.<ref>{{cite web|last=Testerman|first=Janet|title=Kristian Bush of Sugarland Cover Feature|url=http://www.umgnashville.com/artist/detail.aspx?nid=5055&aid=181|work=Knoxville Magazine|access-date=October 27, 2014}}</ref>  As a teenager, Bush stuck with the guitar and began to create original music. It wasn't long before he was writing his own songs and recording homemade albums.<ref>{{cite web|title=An Interview with Kristian Bush of Sugarland|url=http://www.epiphone.com/news-features/news/2005/an-interview-with-kristian-bush-of-sugarland.aspx| publisher= Epiphone| access-date= October 27, 2014}}</ref> He did swimmer electives throughout high school and college, and would write music in his head to the rhythm of his swimming strokes.<ref name="TCI"/>

Bush attended [[Avon Old Farms]] Boarding School in [[Avon, Connecticut|Avon]], [[Connecticut]], graduating in 1988. He then attended [[Emory University]] in [[Atlanta]], earning a degree in Creative Writing.<ref name="Emory Magazine" />  During college, Bush began to connect with Atlanta's growing music scene, often begging his way into clubs, witnessing first-hand success from bands like [[R.E.M.]] and (fellow Emory students) the [[Indigo Girls]].<ref name="Emory Magazine" />

==Musical career==
[[File:Kristian Bush at Ramstein Air Base, Germany.jpg|thumb|Bush performing at the [[Ramstein Air Base]] in [[Germany]] in 2008]]
While attending Emory University, Bush was the lead singer and guitarist in the rock band Storyteller, with fellow Emory students Chris "Tex" Nolter (bass, guitar) and Jon Slatkin (drums). Storyteller covered the Replacement's "I Can't Wait”, Rod Stewart's "Maggie May”, The English Beat's "Mirror in the Bathroom", and Jane's Addiction's "Jane Says”, among other songs, and they performed at numerous bars, campus events and parties in Atlanta.

To date, Bush has won six [[BMI Awards]] for his songwriting abilities, and in 2011 he founded the music publishing company and songwriting collective Songs of the Architect. Recent producing and songwriting collaborations include [[Ellis Paul]], [[Laura Bell Bundy]], [[Matt Nathanson]], [[The dB's|the dB’s]], Martin Johnson of [[Boys Like Girls]], [[Pretty Little Liars]] star [[Lucy Hale]], and up-and-comers including [[Kristina Train]], [[Larkin Poe]], [[Canaan Smith]], [[Lauren Alaina]], [[Jaida Dreyer]] and Alana Springsteen.{{citation needed|date=October 2018}}

=== 1990–2001: Billy Pilgrim ===
{{Main|Billy Pilgrim (band)}}
Shortly after completing college, Bush introduced himself to Atlanta songwriter [[Andrew Hyra]] and his sister Annie, who were performing at a club in Knoxville; the two had recently moved there after completing college. In 1990, Bush played guitar and sang backup vocals on ''Big Back Porch Songs'', an album by the Hyras. ''Big Back Porch Songs'' was never released but Bush was given a copy. Bush released an album shortly afterwards, ''Politics and Pocketchange'', which the Hyras were featured on.<ref name="BP">{{Cite web |url=http://www.billypilgrim.net/biography/index.html |title=Tunes, Technology, and Time Travel: a Billy Pilgrim Biography |access-date=October 26, 2023 |website=Trafalmadore |last=Zimmerman |first=Matthew|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716071728/http://www.billypilgrim.net/biography/index.html |archive-date=July 16, 2011 }}</ref><ref name="AMBP"/> Bush and Andrew Hyra began performing together using connections that Bush made from his time in Storyteller, writing original songs in the meantime. The Hyras had made plans for future performances, but Annie had accepted a job in [[Miami, Florida]]; Bush replaced her.<ref name="BP"/>

After a year of performing, the two drove to Knoxville where they rented two days of studio time, where they recorded 14 original songs, assisted by their producer Danny Browns. The two released their first album together in 1991, ''St. Christopher's Crossing'', independently under the credit Andrew Hyra and Kristian Bush.<ref name="AMBP">{{Cite web |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/billy-pilgrim-mn0000770092 |title=Billy Pilgrim - Biography |access-date=October 25, 2023 |website=[[AllMusic]]}}</ref> They continued performing shows in southeastern college towns, and Bush reached out to various talent agents with their demos; Jen Stark, an intern at [[Atlantic Records]], recceived a copy, which resulted in commotion about them amongst the company. An indie label, Sister Ruby, expressed interest in the duo, and the two made another album for the label; it emphasized songs that weren't used for ''St. Christophers's Crossing'', which were quieter songs that couldn't be played in loud clubs.  The album was called ''Words Like Numbers''. Bush cited a large improvement between the two albums, because "with ''St. Christopher's'' we didn't think, we just did it.  This time we had several weeks to think about what we were recording."<ref name="BP"/> The album was a success in garnering attention; Atlantic Records held a release party for the two, and they were signed to the label that night,<ref name="BP"/> in New York.<ref name="TED"/> The duo name was officially changed to [[Billy Pilgrim (duo)|Billy Pilgrim]], named after a character from [[Kurt Vonnegut]]'s novel ''[[Slaughterhouse-Five]]''.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Billy Pilgrim Review |url=https://core.ac.uk/download/pdf/268642485.pdf |last=Cook |first=Sean |date=February 17, 1994 |pages=2 |work=[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out]]}}</ref><ref name="BP"/><ref name="TOCBP"/>

The duo released the self-titled album ''Billy Pilgrim'' in 1994, in association with producer [[Hugh Padgham]], who had a group of London musicians overdub the master with additional instruments.<ref name="BP"/><ref name="TOCBP">{{Cite web |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/kristian-bush-pre-sugarland-band-billy-pilgrim-lost-album-time-machine/ |title=Kristian Bush's Pre-Sugarland Album Band Billy Pilgrim Releasing Their Long Lost Album [Listen] |date=July 16, 2020 |access-date=October 25, 2023 |website=[[Taste Of Country]] |last=Trapp |first=Phillip}}</ref> Although the album itself received little attention, "Get Me Out Of Here" and "Insomniac", two songs on the album were, receiving heavy airplay on AAA radio. In 1995 they opened on a worldwide tour for [[Melissa Etheridge]], but copies for ''Billy Pilgrim'' weren't made in time to be promoted throughout it.<ref name="BP"/> To increase their momentum, Atlantic Records made the two record another album in December 1994; unprepared, they scrambled to write new material two weeks ahead of the date of recording. They were paired with a group of veteran musicians who emphasized sounds that took away from their original music.<ref name="BP"/> Their second album, ''[[Bloom (Billy Pilgrim album)|Bloom]]'', released in 1995. The lead single "Sweet Louisiana Sound" was a critical and commercial success, making a full rotation on [[VH1]]. At their peak they "traveled all over the world together, just with two acoustic guitars and two voices."<ref name="BPRS">{{Cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/see-kristian-bush-reunite-his-nineties-folk-rock-band-billy-pilgrim-186979/ |title=See Kristian Bush Reunite His Nineties Folk-Rock Band Billy Pilgrim |date=January 22, 2016 |access-date=October 25, 2023 |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |last=Leahey |first=Andrew}}</ref>

Sales for ''Bloom'' were underwhelming, and with increasing focus on [[Hootie and the Blowfish]], Atlantic Records dropped the duo in 1996.<ref name="BP"/><ref name="RLM"/> The two toured sporadically, working on an album for a 1996 release, which never surfaced. Hyra moved to California but still kept in contact with Bush. Billy Pilgrim went silent temporarily as did Bush; he occasionally played at [[Eddie's Attic]], and did production work [[Ellis Paul]], Beth Wood, and [[Evan and Jaron]]. Bush announced the two were making separate solo albums in 1997, but such albums never released. Bush and Hyra collaborated for a "farewell" tour, and although they simply meant they were taking a hiatus, news spread they were disbanding.<ref name="BP"/>

==== 1999–2001: Billy Pilgrim hiatus ====
In 1999, Bush took interest in the newly developing format of online music distribution. He began releasing demos, outtakes, and live performances from Billy Pilgrim on the website [[MP3.com]]. He appreciated that he was able to release music easily without anyone else's approval. Bush partnered with MP3.com to release an old live performance of Billy Pilgrim at Eddie's Attic in 1998, ''Live from Wildhack, MT'', on the website. The performance also contained unreleased songs. Billy Pilgrim released ''Snow Globe'', a Christmas album, in November 1999, and ''9/23/00'', another live performance from Eddie's Attic, released towards the end of the year.<ref name="BP"/>

All the money earned from the downloads on MP3.com Bush used to fund the next album and its physical release. The album, ''Billy In the Time Machine'', was recorded in four separate sessions over the course of eight months. Bush cited [[U2]]{{'}}s ''[[The Joshua Tree]]'' and [[Thom Yorke]] as inspiration for the album. It was released May 12, 2001.<ref name="BP"/> The final works the two made together before unofficially disbanding were compiled into masters tapes. The tapes, as well as their studio, burned in a fire in late 2000.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://magnetmagazine.com/2021/03/24/magnet-television-qa-with-kristian-bush-and-andrew-hyra-billy-pilgrim/ |title=Magnet Television: Q&A With Kristian Bush and Andrew Hyra (Billy Pilgrim) |date=March 24, 2021 |access-date=November 19, 2023 |website=[[Magnet Magazine]]}}</ref><ref name="BP"/> One copy was salvaged from the accident and made into a CD, of which 500 copies were made and distributed at their final performance in 2001 at [[Eddie's Attic]]. The band was never declared disbanded but the two lost contact with each other.<ref name="RLM">{{Cite web |url=https://www.redlightmanagement.com/artists/billy-pilgrim/ |title=Billy Pilgrim - Artist Bio |access-date=October 25, 2023 |website=Red Light Management}}</ref>

=== 2001–2012: Sugarland ===
[[File:Jennifer nettles 2021 1.jpg|thumb|[[Jennifer Nettles]] is the other half of Bush's duo band [[Sugarland]].]]
[[File:Nettles and Bush of Sugarland at 2007 MyCoke Fest in Atlanta.JPG|thumb|Bush performing alongside [[Jennifer Nettles]] ''(left)'' in 2007]]
{{Main|Sugarland}}

At the same time Bush was performing occasionally at Eddie's Attic, so was singer-songwriter [[Jennifer Nettles]]; she had begun performing there at their open mic competitions and was eventually given a recurring performing gig. Nettles had recently concluded her time in other bands and met Atlanta singer-songwriter [[Kristen Hall]] at a bar and discussed their country music endeavors together. Bush later discussed starting a band with Hall in 2002 and held auditions for the lead singer; Nettles was fifth to audition, and Bush said she "blew it out of the water".<ref name="IM"/> In 2003, Bush met with the two at a [[Starbucks]] to discuss starting a band together; the trio officially formed [[Sugarland]] the next day.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.cmt.com/news/ugirjj/sugarlands-jennifer-nettles-gives-credit-to-eddies-attic |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231029232752/https://www.cmt.com/news/ugirjj/sugarlands-jennifer-nettles-gives-credit-to-eddies-attic |url-status=dead |archive-date=October 29, 2023 |title=Sugarland's Jennifer Nettles Gives Credit to Eddie's Attic |date=May 9, 2008 |access-date=October 29, 2023 |website=[[Country Music Television]] |last=Shelburne |first=Craig}}</ref><ref name="NOTEW">{{Cite magazine |url=https://ew.com/article/2008/07/18/sugarland-countrys-hottest-duo/ |title=Sugarland: country's hottest duo |date=July 18, 2008 |access-date=October 31, 2023 |magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |last=Pastor |first=Whitney}}</ref> The name was suggested by Hall; its derived from the town of [[Sugar Land, Texas]], and was picked since it reflected the "sweet" tone of the band.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://americansongwriter.com/behind-the-sweet-history-of-the-band-name-sugarland/ |title=Behind the "Sweet" History of the Band Name: Sugarland |date=February 16, 2023 |access-date=October 29, 2023 |website=[[American Songwriter]] |last=Uitti |first=Jacob}}</ref>

At least one of the three artists wrote or co-wrote all 11 songs on their first album, ''[[Twice the Speed of Life]]''. All three worked on the lead single "[[Baby Girl (Sugarland song)|Baby Girl]]".<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://theboot.com/sugarland-debut-album-released/ |title=18 Years Ago: Sugarland's Debut Album Is Released |date=October 26, 2022 |access-date=October 29, 2023 |website=[[The Boot (website)|The Boot]]}}</ref> Bush described the experience as his "second first record", understanding the experience and knowing the pressure associated with the first attempt.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.cmt.com/news/wc4r7j/cmt-insider-interview-sugarland |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231029231252/https://www.cmt.com/news/wc4r7j/cmt-insider-interview-sugarland |url-status=dead |archive-date=October 29, 2023 |title='CMT Insider' Interview: Sugarland |date=November 20, 2006 |access-date=October 29, 2023 |website=[[Country Music Television]] |last=Lee |first=Lisa}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.fyimusicnews.ca/articles/2015/07/20/conversation-kristian-bush-sugarland |title=A Conversation with... Kristian Bush from Sugarland |date=July 20, 2015 |access-date=October 29, 2023 |website=FYIMusicNews |last=King |first=Bill}}</ref> The trio treated the album like a side project to their other musical endeavors, but understood the potential of it over time.<ref name="NOTEW"/> The songs were written roughly around 2001. In a notably dark period of Bush's life, in light of the downfall of Billy Pilgrim, the death of his mother, and the recent [[September 11 attacks]], he wrote songs that were lighthearted and depicted a life that he wanted to live.<ref name="TED"/> They found success performing live in Knoxville, and Bush bought his first cowboy hat on [[eBay]] in 2003 to prove to his friends he was taking the new endeavor seriously.<ref name="NOTEW"/> They eventually received the attention of [[Mercury Nashville]] in 2004, and landed a recording deal with them to release an album.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.countrythangdaily.com/the-real-story-behind-kristen-halls-split-from-sugarland/ |title=The Real Story Behind Kristen Hall's Split from Sugarland |date=October 22, 2023 |access-date=October 31, 2023 |website=Country Thang Daily}}</ref>

Sugarland broke through in 2004 with the release of their debut single "[[Baby Girl (Sugarland song)|Baby Girl]]", the first single from their multi-platinum debut album ''[[Twice the Speed of Life]]''. The trio became a duo in 2006, when they also released their second album, ''[[Enjoy the Ride (Sugarland album)|Enjoy the Ride]]''. This album produced their first two No.&nbsp;1 singles (in the U.S.), "[[Want To]]" and "[[Settlin']]", and won the duo a Grammy for "[[Stay (Sugarland song)|Stay]]". In 2008 they released their third album, titled ''[[Love on the Inside]]''. This album produced three more No.&nbsp;1 singles with "[[All I Want to Do (Sugarland song)|All I Want to Do]]", "[[Already Gone (Sugarland song)|Already Gone]]"and "[[It Happens]]". Their fourth album, ''[[The Incredible Machine (album)|The Incredible Machine]]'' was released on October 19, 2010, in both a standard and deluxe edition. Upon ''The Incredible Machine'' being certified platinum, Sugarland has sold in excess of 14 million records.<ref>{{cite web | url =http://www.theboot.com/2011/01/31/sugarland-incredible-machine-platinum-sales/ | title =Sugarland Strikes Platinum With Their 'Incredible Machine' | first=Cory |last=Stromblad | date =January 31, 2011 | publisher =The Boot | access-date = January 31, 2011}}</ref> Nettles and Bush also write all of the band's songs.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sugarland Red Dirt Road|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=96pDt53eAk4 |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211219/96pDt53eAk4 |archive-date=December 19, 2021 |url-status=live|work=Youtube| date=May 25, 2010 |access-date=November 14, 2011}}{{cbignore}}</ref> In October 2012, they were inducted into the [[Georgia Music Hall of Fame]].

They have surpassed sales of over 22 million albums worldwide, achieved five No. 1 singles and won numerous awards, including trophies from the [[Grammys]], [[American Music Awards]], [[Academy of Country Music Awards]], [[CMT Music Awards]] and [[CMA Awards]].

====2011–2013: Stage collapse and Sugarland hiatus ====
{{See also|Indiana State Fair stage collapse}}
[[File:USMC-101203-M-5053B-190.jpg|thumb|Bush performing with Nettles in December 2011]]

On August 13, 2011, during their ''Incredible Machine Tour'' at the [[Indiana State Fair]], the [[Indiana State Fair stage collapse|stage collapsed]] due to high winds, killing seven people and injuring 58 others.<ref name=WSJ>''Wall Street Journal''. Jack Nicas, "[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702304356604577339923897959492 Faulty Planning, Stage Cited in Fair Collapse]". April 12, 2012.</ref> At the moment of collapse, Indiana State Fair director Cindy Hoye and [[Indiana State Police|state police]] [[police captain|captain]] Brad Weaver were approaching the stage to announce the concert's cancellation.<ref name=Witt>Witt Associates. [http://www.wittobriens.com/external/content/document/2000/1883990/1/Witt-Associates-Indiana-State-Fair-Report_April2012.pdf ''An Independent Assessment of the August 13, 2011 Indiana State Fair Collapse Incident''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151029161618/http://www.wittobriens.com/external/content/document/2000/1883990/1/Witt-Associates-Indiana-State-Fair-Report_April2012.pdf |date=October 29, 2015 }}. December 4, 2014.</ref> Bush, under the stage in a dressing room, felt the quake and witnessed flying debris break down the stage door and fill the hallway; he had thought a bomb went off. In the immediate aftermath of the collapse he, Nettles, and other crew downstairs were not allowed to leave; crew members attempted to leave but were kept from doing so. Bush was unaware of what happened and was kept in the dark for a long time. He was eventually evacuated to his bus but was forced to remain on the scene. He recalled "all sorts of silence" as Nettles and the downstairs crew watched footage of the accident on the news.<ref name="TT">{{Cite web |url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2015/04/09/kristian-bush-wrote-soothe-pain-stage-collapse-divorce/25548193/ |title=Sugarland's Kristian Bush tells story of stage collapse, divorce |date=April 19, 2015 |access-date=November 18, 2023 |website=[[The Tennessean]] |last=Watts |first=Cindy}}</ref> Bush wrote the following on their Sugarland website:

<blockquote>"Our fans just came to see a show, and it ended in something terrible. My heart is totally broken for the families and friends of those who lost their lives. It’s broken for all the people who got hurt, for the people who were scared. I thank God for every person who lifted a truss, who pushed against that metal to get it off someone; for every person who used a chair as a stretcher. I thank God for every fan and emergency responder, for everyone who ran to the trouble instead of away from it. The courage of those men and women will forever be with me."<ref name="TBISF">{{Cite web |url=https://theboot.com/sugarland-stage-collapse-date/ |title=10 Years Ago: Sugarland's Stage Collapses at the Indiana State Fair |date=2021-08-13 |access-date=2023-11-18 |website=The Boot |last=Thompson |first=Gayle}}</ref></blockquote>

In years following, especially the immediate days following the event, Bush was discouraged from talking about the accident due to pending lawsuits. Sugarland cancelled one upcoming concert and performed two more, concluding the ''Incredible Machine Tour'' in October 2011.<ref name="TBISF"/>

Sugarland announced they would be going on hiatus for a few months to consider their next steps forward.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/sugarland-time-off-jennifer-nettles-solo-album/ |title=Sugarland to Take Time Off to Relax, Jennifer Nettles Considering Solo Album |date=November 10, 2011 |access-date=November 18, 2023 |website=[[Taste of Country]] |last=Dukes |first=Billy}}</ref> Bush returned home and continued working out the details of his pending divorce, finalizing it in November 2011. In light of the stage collapse and what talking about it publicly would mean for his children, he refrained from openly discussing the divorce as well. Within the same month Nettles got married and informed Bush that she was pregnant, and that she wanted to do a solo album, since she wanted more time to experience new things and focus on her family.<ref name="TT"/><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/sugarland-comeback-healing-tragic-indiana-state-fair-stage/story?id=58854723 |title=Sugarland on their comeback and healing after tragic Indiana State Fair stage collapse |date=November 11, 2018 |access-date=November 18, 2023 |website=[[ABC News (United States)|ABC News]] |last=Valiente |first=Alexa}}</ref>

The two agreed to put the band on hiatus indefinitely. Fulfilling their pre-established plans, Bush's final performance as Sugarland before the hiatus was at [[Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino]] on September 2, 2012.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2018/03/30/sugarland-hiatus-reunion-jennifer-nettles-kristian-bush/453789002/ |title=Exclusive: Inside Sugarland's 'Bigger' reasons for hiatus, reunion |date=March 30, 2018 |access-date=November 18, 2023 |website=[[The Tennessean]] |last=Watts |first=Cindy}}</ref> Without the band Bush's schedule was completely empty, which he found "anxiety-driving".<ref name="TCI">{{Cite web |url=https://thecreativeindependent.com/people/musician-and-songwriter-kristian-bush-on-listening-and-learning/ |title=On listening and learning |date=January 22, 2020 |access-date=November 19, 2023 |website=The Creative Independent |last=Rachel |first=Cole}}</ref> Unsure of what to do going forward, Bush purchased a house in Nashville and began reaching out and working with established songwriters in the area, accepting any work that was offered to him. Unable and struggling to freely discuss his circumstances, he began expressing himself through songwriting. Bush mainly wrote music only when he needed to for Sugarland, but now found himself writing songs constantly.<ref name="TT"/>

{{Quote box|quote="You could hear me, but I couldn't tell you." |source= Kristian Bush discussing his circumstances and ''[[Southern Gravity]]'', 2015 ''[[The Tennessean]]'' interview<ref name="TT"/>|width=30em|align=right}}

Bush was encouraged by the people around him to write a solo album. At first he was reluctant to do so, believing that doing so would hurt the image of Sugarland. [[Byron Gallimore]], Sugarland's producer, ensured him that since he was never the primary singer of the band, he wouldn't replace Sugarland on country radio. He began considering the venture, and looked through what songs he had written following the hiatus; he was surprised to find he had a collection of 300 recorded songs, and focused on what collection of songs he should release first.<ref name="TT"/> He began playing and writing for those he had worked with in the past, although they were reluctant to give him an opportunity because they did not know anything about how he performed separately; he realized then that the momentum from Sugarland would not carry over into his potential solo career.<ref name="TED"/>

===2013–2016: Solo career ===

In July 2013, after being drawn to the music and design of the mobile app ''[[My Singing Monsters]]'' while watching his son play, he expressed his praise of the game on [[Twitter]]. The game's director Dave Kerr responded suggesting a collaboration and Bush agreed, performing the mandolin for a monster representation of himself, the "Shugabush".<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/music/2013/07/29/sugarland-kristian-bush-dons-my-singing-monsters-green-suit/2595775/ |title=Sugarland's Kristian Bush dons green monster suit |date=July 29, 2013 |access-date=November 19, 2023 |website=[[USA Today]] |last=Lopez |first=Karina}}</ref> The following October, Bush was invited to perform at the inaugural [[C2C: Country to Country]] festival at the [[The O2 Arena|O2 Arena]] in [[London, England]]. The trip inspired him to release a song as a single to play there, resulting in his solo debut with the song "Love or Money", performed with a full band. The entire audience sang the chorus back to him.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://theboot.com/kristian-bush-love-or-money/ |title=Kristian Bush's "Love or Money" is Sugarland Guitarist's First Solo Single (Listen) |date=March 27, 2013 |access-date=November 19, 2023 |website=The Boot |last=Thompson |first=Gayle}}</ref> The song released in the United States on October 10, 2013.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://theboot.com/kristian-bush-love-or-money-single/ |title=Kristian Bush Releases First Solo Single in the United States |date=October 10, 2013 |access-date=November 19, 2023 |website=The Boot |last=Thompson |first=Gayle}}</ref> ''My Singing Monsters'' would later feature a cover of "Love or Money", with Bush doing a [[gibberish]] rendition of the lyrics.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://eddiesattic.com/event/kristian-bush-friends-thanksgiving-show-2/ |title=Kristian Bush & Friends Thanksgiving Show |date=November 26, 2023 |access-date=November 19, 2023 |website=[[Eddie's Attic]]}}</ref> Bush also hosted "Music Mondays" on his website, where he released his works and discussed the story behind it. He found himself writing and recording music much more frequently, purposefully not thinking about where or when the song would be released. On average he was making about 160 songs a year.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/kristian-bush-love-or-money/ |title=Kristian Bush Excited to Release "Love or Money" to iTunes in the U.S. |date=October 9, 2013 |access-date=November 19, 2023 |website=[[Taste of Country]] |last=Dukes |first=Billy}}</ref>

{{Quote box|quote="We wanted to start with a story that embodied the greatness and power of country music. His studio burned down, his mom passed and he gathered the fortitude to keep going. That’s really where Sugarland came from. When you bring in the success that is Sugarland, this tragedy of the Indiana State Fair stage collapse, then he went on another journey after that — what you end up with is great music and this kind of epic journey of a guy who loves making music." |source= Stokes Nielson, director and producer of ''Walk Tall: The Journey of Sugarland's Kristian Bush''<ref name="Rock on Kristian">{{Cite web |url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2015/09/11/sugarlands-kristian-bush-walks-tall-tv-biography/72102524/ |title=Sugarland's Kristian Bush 'Walks Tall' in TV biography |date=2015-09-12 |access-date=2023-11-19 |website=[[The Tennessean]] |last=Watts |first=Cindy}}</ref> |width=30em|align=right}}

In 2014, Bush signed for Gallimore's [[Streamsound Records]] as a solo artist.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www1.billboard.biz/bbbiz/photos/pdf/2013/BCU_0623.pdf|title=Billboard biz|website=Billboard.biz|access-date=June 8, 2018|archive-date=October 27, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141027161221/http://www1.billboard.biz/bbbiz/photos/pdf/2013/BCU_0623.pdf|url-status=dead}}</ref> Gallimore noticed that Bush was hiding a lot when it came to his current situation, and recognized that it was a "very, very painful" time for him. Two songs on the album, "Southern Gravity" and "[[Trailer Hitch]]", was written with Tim Owens; Owens said that given the kind of person that Bush is, and his talent of writing positive music, he was not surprised he could write happy songs that "sound marginally like Sugarland" despite him being in a dark place.<ref name="TT"/> Many songs from his backlog were shelved for being too sad and outside the scope of music he wanted to release.<ref name="RSSG">{{Cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/kristian-bush-on-joyous-new-lp-born-of-tragedy-its-sunshine-into-a-cave-63580/3/ |title=Kristian Bush on Joyous New LP Born of Tragedy: It's 'Sunshine Into a Cave' |date=April 2, 2015 |access-date=November 19, 2023 |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |last=Dunkerley |first=Neville}}</ref> The solo album consisted of feel-good music and lyrics; Bush himself admitted that he was unsure how that came to be given the circumstances. In an interview with ''[[The Tennessean]]'', Bush said "I think I write wishes. If you can see it, you can probably get there. My story starts now."<ref name="TT"/> He had a lot of self-doubt at the time, believing that the songs weren't any good because he conceived them too easily. He collaborated with the best in his field to ensure people weren't showing positive reception simply because he was famous, including [[Will Jennings]], [[Paul Overstreet]], [[Bob DiPiero]], and [[James Blunt]].<ref name="IM"/>

Bush announced the solo album, ''[[Southern Gravity]]'', in 2014, and released "Trailer Hitch" in July.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.yahoo.com/travel/country-superstar-kristian-bushs-6-favorite-breakfast-93335843692.html |title=Country Superstar Kristian Bush's 6 Favorite Breakfast Joints on the Road |date=July 31, 2014 |access-date=November 19, 2023 |website=[[Yahoo!]] |last=Froelich |first=Paula}}</ref> "Trailer Hitch" peaked at number 21 on the U.S. ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Country Airplay]] chart and at number 25 on the U.S. ''Billboard'' US Country chart. His second single from the album, "Light Me Up" in 2015, also appeared on charts. Bush was fascinated meeting people who were both fans of Sugarland and "Trailer Hitch", but having rarely heard him sing in the former, were surprised to find that he sang the song.<ref name="RSSG"/> ''Southern Gravity'' released April 7, 2015,<ref name="TT"/> appearing on various charts, including but not limited to 160 on ''[[Billboard 200]]'',<ref>{{Cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/kristian-bush/chart-history/tlp/ |title="Kristian Bush Chart History (Billboard 200)" |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]}}</ref> 16 on ''Billboard''{{'}}s [[Top Country Albums]],<ref>{{Cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/kristian-bush/chart-history/clp/ |title="Kristian Bush Chart History (Top Country Albums)" |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]}}</ref> and 5 on ''Billboard''{{'}}s [[Heatseekers Albums]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/kristian-bush/chart-history/tln/ |title="Kristian Bush Chart History (Heatseekers Albums)" |website=[[Billboard (website)|Billboard]]}}</ref> Bush referred to ''Southern Gravity'' as his "third first album". He found the album inspiring, and would listen to it to remind himself that "no matter how hard it gets, you can make things out of the pieces that are smashed."<ref name="IM">{{Cite web |url=https://internationalmusician.org/kristian-bush/ |title=Kristian Bush: Rediscovers His Voice Through Southern Gravity |date=August 31, 2015 |access-date=November 19, 2023 |website=[[International Musician]]}}</ref> In September 2015 Bush was the subject of the television documentary ''Walk Tall: The Journey of Sugarland's Kristian Bush'', directed and produced by Stokes Nelson. It documents Bush's life and highlights his persistence through turbulent times. It featured [[Kix Brooks]], [[Canaan Smith]], and [[Maddie & Tae]], and performances from Bush.<ref name="Rock on Kristian"/>

Bush was a lead performer at the January 2016 30A Songwriters Festival in [[Seaside, Florida]].<ref>{{Cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/kristian-bush-robert-ellis-lead-30a-songwriters-festival-lineup-46039/ |title=Kristian Bush, Robert Ellis Lead 30A Songwriters Festival Lineup |date=December 22, 2015 |access-date=November 19, 2023 |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |last=Freeman |first=Jon}}</ref> Also among the performers at the festival was Hrya and his band, the Smokin' Novas. When Bush learned about Hyra's attendance at his final show he performed "I Won’t Tell" from their album ''Bloom''; Hyra joined him onstage and sang harmony, to the standing ovation from the audience. Bush had been given the green light for a second solo album, and Hyra was a carpenter and performed casually, so no plans for a reformation were made at the time. Bush kept the possibility of doing so open. The week after, Hyra performed harmony for a demo recording for Bush.<ref name="BPR">{{Cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/see-kristian-bush-reunite-his-nineties-folk-rock-band-billy-pilgrim-186979/ |title=See Kristian Bush Reunite His Nineties Folk-Rock Band Billy Pilgrim |date=January 22, 2016 |access-date=November 19, 2023 |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |last=Leahey |first=Andrew}}</ref> In February 2016, Bush signed a new publishing, producing, and label deal with [[Broken Bow Records]], to record under their imprint Wheelhouse Records.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/kristian-bush-bbr-music-group/|title= Kristian Bush Signs New Deal With BBR Music Group| first= Sterling|last= Whitaker|website=[[Taste of Country]]| date= February 6, 2016|access-date=February 6, 2016}}</ref> "Forever Now (Say Yes)", written and performed by Bush, became the new theme song for the TLC reality series ''[[Say Yes to the Dress]]'' when their 14th season premiered on March 4, 2016. Bush also makes a guest appearance on the show later in the season.<ref>{{cite magazine| magazine= Rolling Stone| url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/see-kristian-bush-sing-say-yes-to-the-dress-theme-forever-now-20160307|title= See Kristian Bush Sing 'Say Yes to the Dress' Theme 'Forever Now'| first= Jon|last= Freeman|date= March 7, 2016|access-date=March 7, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/kristian-bush-records-new-theme-for-say-yes-to-the-dress/ |title=Kristian Bush Records New Theme for "Say Yes to the Dress" |date=March 8, 2016 |access-date=November 19, 2023 |website=Sounds Like Nashville |last=Laffer |first=Lauren}}</ref>

=== 2017–2020: Other solo ventures, Sugarland and Billy Pilgrim reformation, and Dark Water ===
After ''Southern Gravity'', Bush worked with [[Lindsay Ell]] to produce her debut EP, ''[[Worth the Wait (EP)]]'', mentoring her on her music endeavors.<ref name="TDSA"/> Also after ''Southern Gravity'', playwright Janece Shaffer reached out to Bush requesting that he write a song about a character for her playwright ''Troubadour''; set in 1951, it's about the life of fictional country star Billy Mason. The song, "Father to the Son", was another song he considered a "wish" as it reflected the relationship he wanted to have with his father.<ref name="TD"/> Shaffer requested a second song, so Bush wrote three songs to pick from; Shaffer used all three. Ultimately, Bush would write the entire soundtrack for the musical. ''Troubadour'' first premiered at the Atlanta [[Alliance Theatre]] in January 28, 2017.<ref name="TD"/><ref>{{cite web|title= Alliance Theatre Goes Big for 2016–17 Season|url= http://www.americantheatre.org/2016/03/24/alliance-theatre-goes-big-for-2016-17-season/|date=March 24, 2016|website= AmericanTheatre.org|publisher= Theatre Communications Group|access-date=March 24, 2016}}</ref> The music felt deeply personal to him, with lyrics that he felt reflected his career and music reflecting that of the 1930's, which Bush drew inspiration from in his music.<ref name="TD">{{Cite web |url=https://americansongwriter.com/kristian-bush-parallels-real-life-on-new-album-troubadour/ |title=Kristian Bush Parallels Real Life on New Album 'Troubadour' |date=February 23, 2022 |access-date=November 19, 2023 |website=[[American Songwriter]] |last=Crone |first=Madeline}}</ref> Bush planned not to release new music until later in 2017, but early exposure from [[Bobby Bones]], a fan of his music, caused him to release "Sing Along". Bush explained that the song was about a past relationship that ended some time after his divorce, with lyrics that would remind them about the good times they had.<ref name="TDSA">{{Cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/country/kristian-bush-sing-along-lyric-video-7693314/ |title=Sugarland's Kristian Bush Premieres 'Sing Along' Lyric Video, Talks 'Accidentally' Writing a Musical |date=February 16, 2017 |access-date=November 19, 2023 |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |last=Dauphin |first=Chuck}}</ref> Bush hoped that they have listened to the song.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/kristian-bush-spent-2-months-dying-father-music/ |title=Kristian Bush Spent Two Months With His Dying Father and it Changed Everything |date=April 11, 2017 |access-date=November 19, 2023 |website=[[Taste of Country]] |last=Dukes |first=Billy}}</ref>

At the [[51st Annual Country Music Association Awards]] in 2017, Sugarland officially reunited following a five year hiatus and announced that they were working on new music together.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://theboot.com/sugarland-new-music-2018-tour-dates/|title = It's Official: Sugarland Are Returning with New Music!| website=The Boot | date=November 9, 2017 }}</ref> Their first full-band shows were at the [[C2C: Country to Country]] festival in March 2018. Their sixth studio album, ''[[Bigger (album)|Bigger]]'' was released on June 8, 2019.

On May 31, 2019, Bush released a new EP, ''Summertime Six Pack''.<ref name="Knox News">{{cite web|url=https://www.knoxnews.com/story/entertainment/music/2019/06/12/kristian-bush-sugarland-talks-forming-new-band-new-music/1350922001/|title=Knoxville's Kristian Bush talks forming new band, releasing more Sugarland music|last=Jones|first=Maggie|work=Knox News|date=June 12, 2019|access-date=July 8, 2019}}</ref>

Bush has also co-written with actress and singer [[Rita Wilson]] on three of her albums; ''Rita Wilson'', ''Bigger Picture'', and ''Halfway to Home''. He toured with her in 2019.<ref name="Knox News"/>

In 2019 Bush formed a new band with his brother Brandon, and friend Benji Shanks called Dark Water. He calls the band "an amazing experience", and he "can't wait for people to hear it."<ref name="Knox News"/>

==== 2022–2024: ''52'' and Billy Pilgrim====
Throughout 2022 and 2023, Bush released [[52 (album series)|four albums consisting of 52 songs]] to celebrate his 52nd birthday.<ref name="MRTY">{{Cite web |url=https://musicrow.com/2023/02/kristian-bush-gears-up-for-final-installment-of-52-album-series-in-march/ |title=Kristian Bush Gears Up For Final Installment Of '52' Album Series In March |date=February 10, 2023 |access-date=October 18, 2023 |website=[[MusicRow]] |last=Hollabaugh |first=Lorie}}</ref> The music consisted of unreleased works dating back to as early as 2006, which he was inspired to release after creating a [[YouTube]] channel to release old recordings of performances from Billy Pilgrim.<ref name="BB">{{Cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/country/exclusive-kristian-bush-tees-up-four-album-solo-project-i-am-motivated-by-stories-1235038068/ |title=Kristian Bush Tees Up Four-Album Solo Project: 'I Am Motivated by Stories' (Exclusive) |date=March 3, 2022 |access-date=October 12, 2023 |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |last=Nicholson |first=Jessica}}</ref> ''[[ATL x BNA|52 | ATL x BNA]]'' released on March 25, 2022, and consisted of music that blended country music from [[Nashville, Tennessee]] and [[R&B]] from [[Atlanta, Georgia]].<ref name="AJC">{{Cite web |url=https://www.ajc.com/life/radiotvtalk-blog/sugarlands-kristian-bush-releasing-52-songs-to-celebrate-52-years-on-earth/XS7VRP2TONCQHEZPWIJRK624UE/ |title=Sugarland's Kristian Bush releasing 52 songs to celebrate 52 years on earth |date=March 24, 2022 |access-date=October 15, 2023 |website=[[The Atlanta Journal-Constitution]] |last=Ho |first=Rodney}}</ref><ref name="MR">{{Cite web |url=https://musicrow.com/2022/03/kristian-bush-celebrates-turning-52-with-first-installment-of-new-52-song-project/ |title=Kristian Bush Celebrates Turning 52 With First Installment Of New 52-Song Project |date=March 4, 2022 |access-date=October 15, 2023 |website=[[MusicRow]] |last=Hollabaugh |first=Lorie}}</ref> ''[[In The Key Of Summer|52 | In The Key Of Summer]]'' released on June 24, 2022, featuring music that focused on the summer season.<ref name="TMU">{{Cite web |url=https://themusicuniverse.com/kristian-bush-announces-52-key-summer/ |title=Kristian Bush announces '52 – In The Key of Summer' |date=June 3, 2022 |access-date=October 15, 2023 |website=The Music Universe |last=Iahn |first=Buddy}}</ref><ref name="PM">{{Cite web |url=https://people.com/country/kristian-bush-to-release-52-songs-to-commemorate-his-52nd-birthday/ |title=Kristian Bush to Release 52 Songs to Commemorate His 52nd Birthday – Thanks to Vince Gill |date=August 23, 2022 |access-date=October 12, 2023 |website=[[People (magazine)|People]] |last=Watts |first=Cindy}}</ref> ''[[New Blue (album)|52 | New Blue]]'' was released on September 30, 2022, and consisted of songs that reflected Bush's folk rock music of the 1990s and Billy Pilgrim.<ref name="CMTNB">{{Cite web |url=https://www.cmt.com/news/d13ijj/kristian-bush-revisits-rock-roots-to-discover-new-blue-the-third-volume-of-52 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221121011813/https://www.cmt.com/news/d13ijj/kristian-bush-revisits-rock-roots-to-discover-new-blue-the-third-volume-of-52 |url-status=dead |archive-date=November 21, 2022 |title=Kristian Bush Revisits Rock Roots to Discover "New Blue", the Third Volume of "52" |date=November 18, 2022 |access-date=October 15, 2023 |website=[[Country Music Television]] |last=Goldstein |first=Tiffany}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://musicrow.com/2022/09/kristian-bush-unveils-third-volume-of-album-series-with-new-blue/ |title=Kristian Bush Unveils Third Volume Of Album Series With 'New Blue' |date=September 6, 2022 |access-date=October 18, 2023 |website=[[MusicRow]] |last=Hollabaugh |first=Lorie}}</ref> The final album of the collection, ''[[This Year|52 | This Year]]'', released on March 10, 2023, and consisted of music that focused on true love and a reflection of Bush's career in the music industry.<ref name="MRTY"/>

Billy Pilgrim began performing again in 2023. In 2024 they performed at the Grand Old Opry.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.opry.com/artists/billy-pilgrim | title=Billy Pilgrim &#124; Opry }}</ref> In May 2024 the duo played 3 sold-out shows at Eddie's Attic outside Atlanta.

==Radio==
On [[BBC Radio 2 Country]], Bush presented 'Country Duos', selecting some of his favourite country songs. He presented coverage of the 2017 [[CMA Music Festival]] on [[BBC Radio 2]].

==Personal life==
Bush has a son and a daughter from his marriage, which ended in 2011.<ref name="Rolling Stone">{{cite magazine|last1=Dunkerly|first1=Beville|title=Kristian Bush on Joyous New LP Born of Tragedy: It's 'Sunshine Into a Cave'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/features/kristian-bush-on-joyous-new-lp-born-of-tragedy-its-sunshine-into-a-cave-20150402|magazine=Rolling Stone|date=April 2, 2015|access-date=May 6, 2016}}</ref>

Bush's brother Brandon is a former member of the rock group [[Train (band)|Train]], and also tours with Sugarland, Billy Pilgrim and Kristian's solo project as a keyboardist.

'''Larry Campbell''' (born February 21, 1955) is an American singer and multi-instrumentalist who plays many stringed instruments (including guitar, [[mandolin]], [[pedal steel guitar]], [[slide guitar]], and violin) in genres including country, folk, blues, and rock. Campbell is best known for his time as part of [[Bob Dylan]]'s [[Never Ending Tour]] band from 1997 to 2004, his association with [[Levon Helm]] of [[The Band]], and the musical director of the Midnight Rambles.

Larry Campbell also has extensive experience as a studio musician. Over his 40-plus year career he has recorded with such artists as Levon Helm, [[Judy Collins]], [[Lucy Kaplansky]], [[Richard Shindell]], [[Linda Thompson (singer)|Linda Thompson]], [[Sheryl Crow]], [[Chris Castle]], [[Paul Simon]], [[B. B. King]], [[Willie Nelson]], [[Eric Andersen]], [[Buddy and Julie Miller]], [[Kinky Friedman]], [[Little Feat]], [[Hot Tuna]], [[Cyndi Lauper]], [[k.d. lang]], [[Anastasia Barzee]], [[Rosanne Cash]] and [[Ayọ]], among others.

== Biography ==
During the 1970s and 1980s, Campbell performed regularly on New York City's burgeoning [[country music]] scene, at well-known venues such as [[Greenwich Village]]'s legendary [[Lone Star Cafe]], City Limits, The Rodeo Bar, and O'Lunney's, near the [[United Nations]]. He contributed his talents to several musicals.

Beginning in the late 1970s, Campbell was also a member of The Woodstock Mountains Revue, a unique folk group that featured Artie & [[Happy Traum]], [[Pat Alger]], [[Jim Rooney (music)|Jim Rooney]], [[Bill Keith (musician)|Bill Keith]], [[John Herald]], [[Eric Andersen]] and [[John Sebastian]].<ref>{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p28322/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Biography: Woodstock Mountain Revue|last=Ruhlmann|first=William|publisher=Allmusic|accessdate=May 21, 2010}}</ref>

In 1982, Campbell performed in the orchestra for ''Alaska – The Musical'', playing [[fiddle]], acoustic and electric guitar, [[pedal steel]] and [[banjo]]. Campbell also performed in the orchestra for ''[[Big River (musical)|Big River]]'' in 1985, and ''Rhythm Ranch'' in 1989. In addition, he played pedal steel guitar, banjo, fiddle and guitar for the entire run of ''[[The Will Rogers Follies]]'', which opened on Broadway on May 1, 1991.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Larry Campbell – Broadway Cast & Staff {{!}} IBDB |url=https://www.ibdb.com/broadway-cast-staff/larry-campbell-389223 |access-date=2024-01-01 |website=www.ibdb.com}}</ref>

Campbell was a member of [[Bob Dylan]]'s "Never Ending Tour" band from March 31, 1997, until November 21, 2004.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Padgett |first=Ray |title=Larry Campbell Goes Deep on His Eight Years with Bob Dylan |url=https://www.flaggingdown.com/p/larry-campbell-goes-deep-on-his-eight |access-date=2024-01-01 |website=www.flaggingdown.com |language=en}}</ref> Through his association with Dylan's bass player [[Tony Garnier (musician)|Tony Garnier]], Campbell joined the band, replacing John Jackson as a guitarist, and expanded the role to multi-instrumentalist, playing instruments such as cittern, violin/fiddle, pedal steel guitar, lap steel guitar, mandolin, banjo, and slide guitar.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2020-05-22 |title=The Beginner's Guide to Bob Dylan's Never Ending Tour |url=https://pitchfork.com/thepitch/the-beginners-guide-to-bob-dylans-never-ending-tour/ |access-date=2024-01-01 |website=Pitchfork |language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite web |date=2012-04-20 |title=Levon Helm Remembered: Larry Campbell Talks (2007) |url=https://jambands.com/features/2012/04/20/levon-helm-remembered-larry-campbell-talks-2007/ |access-date=2024-01-01 |website=Jambands |language=en-US}}</ref>

Since Campbell's departure from Dylan's band, he has continued to make guest appearances with various artists and live acts including [[Peter Wolf]], [[Elvis Costello]], [[Emmylou Harris]], [[Rosanne Cash]], [[Furthur (band)|Furthur]], and [[Phil and Friends]]. He has also produced albums for many artists, including [[Jorma Kaukonen]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.redhouserecords.com/store/aint-no-hurry|title=Ain't in No Hurry|date=May 28, 2015|publisher=}}</ref>

Campbell toured regularly with [[Levon Helm]], in addition to producing Helm's two Grammy-winning albums, ''[[Dirt Farmer]]'' and ''[[Electric Dirt]],'' and acting as the musical director for Helm's Midnight Ramble concerts.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/268942/levon-helm-going-electric-this-june|title=Levon Helm Going "Electric" This June|date=April 14, 2009|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=November 24, 2010}}</ref><ref name=":0" />

On September 18, 2008, at the 7th Annual [[Americana Music Association]] Honors and Awards Show, Campbell was presented with The Award for Lifetime Achievement for an Instrumentalist.<ref>{{cite web |title=Awards – 2008 |url=https://americanamusic.org/awards/2008 |accessdate=March 28, 2020 |website=AmericanaMusic |publisher=The Americana Music Association}}</ref>

Campbell played banjo, fiddle, and pedal steel on [[The Black Crowes]] 2009 album ''[[Before the Frost...Until the Freeze]]''. He also appears on the [[Outlaw Country]] band ''[[Whitey Morgan and the 78's (album)|Whitey Morgan and the 78's]]'' recorded at Levon Helm's studio in December 2009 and January 2010, and ''Last Bird Home'' by [[Chris Castle]], also recorded at Levon's studio in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goerie.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20110915/ENTERTAINMENT0301/309149867 |title=Americana songwriter, Womacks play Edinboro, Erie gigs|publisher=GoErie.com|date=September 15, 2011|accessdate=July 25, 2015}}</ref>

Campbell played guitar, pedal steel, banjo, slide, mandolin, and fiddle on [[Dan Brenner]]'s 2011 album ''Little Dark Angel'' produced by ten-time Grammy winner [[Jay Newland]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Jay Newland Discography|url=http://www.jdmanagement.com/jaynewland/newlanddiscography.pdf|publisher=Jdmanagement.com|accessdate=July 25, 2015|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131021210825/http://www.jdmanagement.com/jaynewland/newlanddiscography.pdf|archivedate=October 21, 2013}}</ref>

In 2012, Campbell won a Grammy award for the 2011 release ''Ramble at the Ryman''.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Larry Campbell {{!}} Artist {{!}} GRAMMY.com |url=https://www.grammy.com/artists/larry-campbell/8677 |access-date=2024-01-01 |website=www.grammy.com}}</ref>

Campbell and his wife, Teresa Williams, released a self-titled album on June 23, 2015, on [[Red House Records]].<ref>{{Cite news |last=Dougherty |first=Steve |date=2015-06-17 |title=Backups Larry Campbell and Teresa Williams Step Forward |language=en-US |work=Wall Street Journal |url=http://www.wsj.com/articles/backups-larry-campbell-and-teresa-williams-step-forward-1434562763 |access-date=2024-01-01 |issn=0099-9660}}</ref>

In 2019, Campbell and his wife filled in for [[Little Feat]] guitarist [[Paul Barrere]] during the band's 50th Anniversary Tour. The duo played with the band for most of the tour, from October 7–24, with [[Scott Sharrard]] taking over for the tour's last two dates on October 26 and 27, 2019.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Kahn |first1=Andy |title=Larry Campbell, Teresa Williams & Scott Sharrard To Fill-In For Little Feat's Paul Barrere |url=https://www.jambase.com/article/little-feat-paul-barrere-larry-campbell-teresa-williams-scott-sharrard |website=JamBase |accessdate=March 28, 2020}}</ref> The duo's stint with Little Feat came shortly before Barrere's death on October 26, 2019.<ref>{{cite web |title=Paul Barrere: July 3, 1948 – October 26, 2019 |url=https://www.littlefeat.net/news.html?n_id=3859 |website=Little Feat |accessdate=March 28, 2020}}</ref>

== Personal life ==
Campbell is married to singer Teresa Williams.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jambands.com/features/2007/04/22/larry-campbell-rock-n-rolls-right-hand-man|title=Larry Campbell: Rock N Rolls Right Hand Man|date=April 22, 2007|publisher=[[Relix]] Media Group|accessdate=November 24, 2010}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web |last=Blickenstaff |first=Jacob |title=The enduring musical romance of Larry Campbell and Teresa Williams |url=https://www.motherjones.com/media/2015/12/larry-campbell-teresa-williams-interview/ |access-date=2024-01-01 |website=Mother Jones |language=en-US}}</ref> Williams and Campbell met in New York City while playing country music in the 1980s.<ref name=":1" /> They live in Woodstock, New York.<ref name=":2">{{Cite magazine |last=Browne |first=David |date=2020-05-18 |title=Larry Campbell and Teresa Williams Celebrate His COVID-19 Recovery in Song |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/larry-campbell-teresa-williams-covid-19-let-us-get-together-right-down-here-1001337/ |access-date=2024-01-01 |magazine=Rolling Stone |language=en-US}}</ref>

On March 24, 2020, Williams, announced that Campbell had been diagnosed with [[COVID-19]] amidst the [[COVID-19 pandemic]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Barry |first1=John |title=Coronavirus: Musician Larry Campbell tests positive; played with Bob Dylan, Levon Helm |url=https://www.poughkeepsiejournal.com/story/news/local/2020/03/25/coronavirus-larry-campbell-played-bob-dylan-tests-positive/5077126002/ |website=Poughkeepsie Journal |publisher=USA Today |accessdate=March 28, 2020}}</ref> After a two-week illness, the couple released a performance of Rev. Gary Davis's "Let Us Get Together Right Down Here".<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/larry-campbell-coronavirus-interview-976353/|title=Veteran Rock Guitarist Larry Campbell on Battling Coronavirus: 'This Thing Has Been a Beast'|first1=David|last1=Browne|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=April 2, 2020}}</ref><ref name=":2" />

'''Roland Kent LaVoie''' (born July 31, 1943), better known by his stage name '''Lobo''' (which is Spanish for [[wolf]]), is an American singer-songwriter who was successful in the 1970s, scoring several U.S. Top 10 hits including "[[Me and You and a Dog Named Boo]]", "[[I'd Love You to Want Me]]", and "[[Don't Expect Me to Be Your Friend]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musicvf.com/Lobo.art|title=Lobo Songs (Top Songs/Chart Singles Discography)|publisher=Musicvf.com|access-date=May 8, 2011}}</ref> These three songs, along with "[[Where Were You When I Was Falling in Love]]", gave Lobo four chart toppers on the [[Adult Contemporary (chart)|Easy Listening/Hot Adult Contemporary]] chart.

==Career==
===1961–1970: Early years===
Born in [[Tallahassee, Florida]], LaVoie was raised by his mother in [[Winter Haven, Florida]], with his six siblings. He began his musical career in 1961 as a member of a local band, The Rumours. The band included [[Gram Parsons]] and [[Jim Stafford]], as well as drummer Jon Corneal, who later joined Parsons's [[International Submarine Band]].<ref name=BandBoxRecords>{{cite web|url=https://kimsloans.wordpress.com/tag/lobo-with-the-rumours-1960s-band-with-gram-parsons/|title=Lobo with the Rumours|website=PopBopRocktilUDrop|date=6 March 2021}}</ref>

In 1964, while attending the [[University of South Florida]], LaVoie joined a band called the Sugar Beats<ref name=BandBoxRecords /> and met producer [[Phil Gernhard]]. He recorded a regional hit for the band, a cover of [[Johnny Rivers]]'s song, "What Am I Doing Here?"<ref name=BandBoxRecords />

During the 1960s, LaVoie performed with many other bands, including US Male, The Uglies, and Me and the Other Guys.<ref name=BandBoxRecords /> It was in the latter band that he met musician Billy Aerts, who became a member of Lobo's touring band in the early 1970s and produced Lobo's comeback album in 1989.

Again working with Gernhard, his first solo record was released in 1969 on [[Laurie Records]]. It included the original tracks "Happy Days in New York City" backed with "My Friend Is Here".

===1971–1975: Success with Big Tree===
By 1971, LaVoie had started calling himself Lobo (Spanish for [[wolf]]). Gernhard was an executive for [[Big Tree Records]], and the company released his first single, "[[Me and You and a Dog Named Boo]]", in March 1971.  The first major hit for the label, it reached No. 5 in the US and No. 4 in the UK by May, launching a successful series of singles. It sold over one million copies and was awarded a [[music recording sales certification|gold disc]] in September 1971.<ref name="The Book of Golden Discs">{{cite book
| first= Joseph
| last= Murrells
| year= 1978
| title= The Book of Golden Discs
| edition= 2nd
| publisher= Barrie and Jenkins Ltd
| location= London
| page= [https://archive.org/details/bookofgoldendisc00murr/page/297 297]
| isbn= 0-214-20512-6
| url-access= registration
| url= https://archive.org/details/bookofgoldendisc00murr/page/297
}}</ref>

His debut album, ''Introducing Lobo'', came in  May 1971. In June his second single, "She Didn't Do Magic", was released. In September, "California Kid and Reemo" was released, followed by ''The Albatross''. When Big Tree Records merged with [[Bell Records]], Lobo's second project album ''Close Up'' was never released.

Under the Lobo alias, he then released ''Of a Simple Man'' in 1972, which included back-to-back U.S. Top 10 hits, including "[[I'd Love You to Want Me]]" (No. 2, November 18–25, 1972) and "[[Don't Expect Me to Be Your Friend]]" (No. 8, February 17–24, 1973).  The former became Lobo's biggest hit, a million-seller gaining gold disc status in November 1972<ref name="The Book of Golden Discs"/> and internationally reaching No. 1 in Germany in December 1973 and No. 5 in the United Kingdom in July 1974.

With the release of ''Calumet'' in 1973, Lobo had three more [[Top 40]] hits: "It Sure Took a Long, Long Time", "[[How Can I Tell Her]]", and "Standing at the End of the Line". He made an appearance on ''[[American Bandstand]]'' that year. There were two further minor hit singles from the album: "There Ain't No Way" and "Love Me for What I Am".

In June 1974 Lobo's fourth album, ''Just a Singer'', was released. It was the first album by Lobo to contain tracks not written by him. The only single from the album was "Rings". "Don't Tell Me Goodnight" in 1975 became his last Top 30 single for Big Tree. Lobo also released the album, ''A Cowboy Afraid of Horses'', with "Would I Still Have You" released as a single. The label followed it up with a compilation album that year entitled ''The Best of Lobo''.

===1976–1985: Curb Records, and move to Nashville===
In 1976 Lobo broke away from Big Tree, releasing the album ''Come with Me'' in Europe on the [[Philips Records|Philips]] label.  "At First Sight" and "It's Everywhere" were the singles.  Neither was released in the US.

Lobo signed with [[Curb Records]] in 1977, releasing the single "Afterglow", co-produced by Lobo and Gernhard, and in 1978 "You Are All I'll Ever Need".  No full-length album materialized from these sessions.

In 1979 Lobo was signed to Curb/[[MCA Records]], where he worked with producer [[Bob Montgomery (musician)|Bob Montgomery]], releasing the single "Where Were You When I Was Falling in Love", which reached No. 23.  The song also reached No. 1 on the Adult Contemporary chart.  He also released his first US album in four years, ''Lobo''. Other singles for Curb were "Holding On for Dear Love", "With a Love Like Ours", and "Fight Fire with Fire".

Reportedly dissatisfied with the production of his records, Lobo sought a release from his Curb contract.  He moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] and, in 1981, started his [[Private brand|own label]], Lobo Records, releasing several singles including "I Don't Want to Want You" (written by his brother, Roger LaVoie), "Come Looking for Me", and "Living My Life Without You", all of which charted in the country charts.  He also released "Bull Smith Can't Dance the Cotton Eye Joe" with the group Wolfpack, which included Narvel Felts and Kenny Earl.

Lobo Records was renamed Evergreen Records in 1985.  The label released two of his singles: "Am I Going Crazy" and "Paint the Town Blue", the latter a duet with Robin Lee.

===1987–present: Asian popularity and recent years===
Although he is far less followed now in the United States, Lobo's popularity grew in Asia, fanned by the release of his [[greatest hits]] compilations in 1987 and 1988. This encouraged him to release in 1989 his first new album in 10 years, entitled ''Am I Going Crazy''. It was recorded in [[Taiwan]] on UFO/WEA Records and was produced by Billy Aerts. He signed a multi-album deal with PonyCanyon Records in Singapore, and in 1994 released ''Asian Moon'', repackaging some of the tracks from ''Am I Going Crazy'' along with newly recorded material. His follow-up album ''Classic Hits'' in 1995 were re-recordings of Lobo hits and some [[cover version]]s. In 1996 he released the album ''Sometimes'', containing all new original songs.

On another Asian label, Springroll Entertainment, he released ''You Must Remember This'' in 1997, an album of [[pop standards]] that was released in two formats, one with vocals and the other with instrumental tracks.

In 2000, Lobo signed with a German record company, Gmbh Entertainment, and recorded a few tracks for various hits CDs. He also co-wrote two [[Christmas music|Christmas songs]] with Billy Aerts, "A Big Kid's Christmas" and "Late Christmas Eve", which have been released on various Christmas compilations from 2000 to present. Singles recorded during this period include "[[Let It Be Me (The Everly Brothers song)|Let It Be Me]]", "Who'll Stop the Rain", and "Different Drum".

In 2006, based on his Asian popularity, he toured in Southeast Asia. In 2008, Lobo released ''Out of Time'' with old favorites and some new songs. A tribute album to the original era of the early Lobo recordings was made available from the website.

'''Loggins and Messina''' was an American [[pop rock]] duo consisting of [[Kenny Loggins]] and [[Jim Messina (musician)|Jim Messina]], who achieved major chart success during the early-mid 1970s. Among their well-known songs are "[[Danny's Song]]", "[[House at Pooh Corner (song)|House at Pooh Corner]]", and "[[Your Mama Don't Dance]]". After selling more than 16 million records and becoming one of the leading musical duos of the 1970s,<ref name="Thibodeaux">"Together again: Kenny Loggins and [[Jim Messina (musician)|Jim Messina]] bring their hits to Biloxi," by Ron Thibodeaux, The Times-Picayune (New Orleans), July 29, 2005.</ref> Loggins and Messina separated in 1976. Although Messina would find only limited popularity following the breakup, Loggins went on to achieve major chart success in the 1980s. In 2005 and again in 2009, Loggins and Messina reformed for tours in the United States.

==History==
===Initial career 1971–1976===
[[Jim Messina (musician)|Jim Messina]], formerly of [[Buffalo Springfield]] and [[Poco (band)|Poco]], was working as an independent record producer for [[Columbia Records]] in 1970 when he met [[Kenny Loggins]], a little-known singer/songwriter and guitarist who was signed to [[ABC-Dunhill]] as a staff songwriter.<ref name="Larkin">{{cite book|title=[[Encyclopedia of Popular Music|The Virgin Encyclopedia of Popular Music]]|editor-first=Colin|editor-last=Larkin|editor-link=Colin Larkin (writer)|publisher=[[Virgin Books]]|date=1997|edition=Concise|isbn=1-85227-745-9|page=766}}</ref>

The two recorded a number of Loggins' compositions in Messina's home living room. When Columbia signed Loggins to a six-album contract (with the assistance of Messina), recording began in earnest for Loggins' debut album, with Messina as producer. Messina originally intended to lend his name to the Loggins project only to help introduce the unknown Loggins to Messina's well-established Buffalo Springfield and Poco audiences. However, by the time the album was completed, Messina had contributed so much to the album – in terms of songwriting, arrangement, instrumentation, and vocals – that an "accidental" duo was born.

Their debut album was released November 1971 as ''Kenny Loggins with Jim Messina [[Sittin' In (Loggins and Messina album)|Sittin' In]]''. The album's first single release, the Caribbean-flavored "[[Vahevala]]" (or "Vahevella" or "Vaheevella"), found top 3 success on Chicago's [[WCFL (AM)|WCFL]] on May 18, 1972.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oldiesloon.com/ilc/wcfl051872.htm|title=WCFL - all hit music in the Midwest|publisher=Oldiesloon.com|date=May 18, 1972|access-date=January 5, 2013}}</ref> "Vahevala" and "Nobody But You" both reached the [[Hot 100]]. Although at first the album went unnoticed by radio upon release, it eventually gained traction by autumn 1972, particularly on college campuses, where the pair toured heavily. Loggins' and Messina's harmonies meshed so well that what was begun as a one-off album became an entity unto itself. Audiences regarded the pair as a genuine duo rather than as a solo act with a well-known producer. Instead of just continuing to produce Loggins as a sole performer, they decided to record as a duo: Loggins and Messina.<ref name="Larkin"/>

On March 3, 1973, Loggins and Messina played Carnegie Hall. Ian Dove in the ''New York Times'' called it a "near-perfect rock 'n' roll concert".<ref>{{Cite news|date=March 3, 1973|title=LOGGINS AND MESSINA PLAY CARNEGIE ROCK (Published 1973)|language=en-US|work=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1973/03/03/archives/loggins-and-messina-play-carnegie-rock.html|access-date=March 13, 2021|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>

"When our first album, ''[[Sittin' In (Loggins and Messina album)|Sittin' In]]'', came out, we started receiving a lot of excitement about the music and good sales," Messina recalled in 2005. "We had a choice. It was either I now go on and continue to produce him and we do the solo career or we stay together and let this work. For me, I did not desire to go back out on the road. I had had enough of that, and I wanted to produce records. But [[Clive Davis]] (then president of the record company) intervened and said, 'You know, I think you'd be making a mistake if you guys didn't take this opportunity. Things like this only happen once in a lifetime. It may merit you sleeping on it overnight and making a decision that will be in your best interest.' He was absolutely correct. Kenny made the decision as well. It delayed his solo career, but it gave him an opportunity, I think, to have one."<ref name="Thibodeaux" />

Messina assembled The Kenny Loggins Band by summoning old friends, bassist Larry Sims and drummer Merel Bregante, formerly of [[The Sunshine Company]], multireedist [[Jon Clarke (musician)|Jon Clarke]], and violinist/multireedist Al Garth. Famed [[Grammy]]-winning keyboardist, songwriter and record producer [[Michael Omartian]] played keyboards on the [[Sittin' In (Loggins and Messina album)|debut]], [[Loggins and Messina (album)|second]] and [[Full Sail (Loggins and Messina album)|third]] albums, but did not join them on tour. Los Angeles–based session percussionist [[Milt Holland]] played on all of the duo's studio albums, but like Omartian, he did not tour with them.<ref>{{cite web|last=Flans |first=Robyn |url=http://www.mixonline.com/news/profiles/classic-tracks-loggins-messinas-vahevala/375146 |title=Classic Tracks: Loggins & Messina's 'Vahevala' |publisher=Mixonline |date=September 1, 2004 |access-date=August 26, 2015}}</ref>

Over the next four years, from 1972 to 1976, they produced four more studio albums of original material, plus one album of [[Cover version|covers]] of other artists' material (''[[So Fine (Loggins and Messina album)|So Fine]]''), and two live albums. They sold 16 million records and were the most successful duo of the early 1970s, surpassed later in the decade only by [[Hall & Oates]].<ref name="Thibodeaux" /> They charted three top 20 singles from the second and third albums: "[[Your Mama Don't Dance]]" (No. 4), "[[Thinking of You (Loggins and Messina song)|Thinking of You]]" (No. 18), and "[[My Music (song)|My Music]]" (No. 16). Their work was covered by other prominent artists, including [[Lynn Anderson]], who recorded "[[Listen to a Country Song (song)|Listen to a Country Song]]" in 1972 and reached No. 3 on the charts, and [[Anne Murray]], who reached the U.S. top ten with "[[Danny's Song]]" in early 1973 and the U.S. top twenty with "[[A Love Song (Loggins and Messina song)|A Love Song]]" in early 1974. The later studio albums, ''[[Mother Lode (album)|Mother Lode]]'' (1974), ''[[Native Sons (Loggins and Messina album)|Native Sons]]'' (1976), often found both Loggins and Messina more as two solo artists sharing the same record rather than as a genuine partnership. As both Loggins and Messina noted in 2005, their collaboration eventually became more a competition.

Never really a team of true equals because of the initial teacher–apprentice nature of their music experience levels, the pair had quietly, amicably parted in 1976. Their final studio album of original material, ''[[Native Sons (Loggins and Messina album)|Native Sons]]'', was released January 1976. Later that year the duo went on a final tour, <ref name="Larkin"/> though prior to the start of the tour, Loggins accidentally cut his hand with a [[craft knife]] while practicing his wood-carving hobby at home which required surgery, thereby preventing him from playing guitar for most of that final tour. The final two concert dates of Loggins & Messina - as a duo - were in [[Honolulu]], Hawaii, at the [[Neil S. Blaisdell Center]], on September 24 and 25, 1976, upon which the duo then parted to embark on solo careers. Messina found solo success elusive, but Loggins went on to become one of the biggest hitmakers of the 1980s.

A greatest-hits album, ''[[The Best of Friends (album)|The Best of Friends]]'', was released in November 1976, two months after the duo had ended.  In January 1977, a second live album (from concerts in 1975 and 1976), ''[[Finale (album)|Finale]]'', was released, more by record company decision than one intended by the artists.

===Reformation===
The two reunited in 2005 to choose tracks for an expanded compilation album of singles and album cuts ''[[The Best: Sittin' In Again]]'', which proved successful enough for them to embark on tour together. Their successful "Sittin' In Again" tour was launched in mid-2005 and played-out the remainder of the year. They also released an album that year of the tour. "Every couple of years we'd talk about it, but I was having too much fun as a solo artist," Loggins said that summer. "It was very rewarding for me, and I wasn't ready to share the reins. I still had a lot of stuff to do on my own, to prove myself and to express myself, in a way that wouldn't have fit in with Loggins and Messina."<ref name="Thibodeaux" />

The two were pleased enough to consider future Loggins and Messina projects and the two also toured in 2009. "Like most relationships, we were a moment in time," Loggins said. "It's just really fun to be able to go back and celebrate that and just sort of really honor each other as grown men, in a way we never really did back then. We were young and competitive and didn't realize that it wasn't necessarily all about getting your way, but you learn that if you grow up."<ref name="Thibodeaux" />

Their backing band changed from album to album, with the core members listed below. Some albums featured backing members who later were well-known in their own right; [[John Townsend (artist)|John Townsend]] and [[Ed Sanford]], later of the [[Sanford-Townsend Band]] ("[[Smoke from a Distant Fire]]"), contributed vocals and songwriting to the ''Native Sons'', their final studio album.

==Members==
*[[Kenny Loggins]] &ndash; vocals, rhythm guitar, acoustic guitar, harmonica 
*[[Jim Messina (musician)|Jim Messina]] &ndash; vocals, lead guitar, acoustic guitar, [[mandolin]], [[Dobro]]

;Supporting personnel
*Al Garth &ndash; tenor saxophone, bass clarinet, alto saxophone, violin, [[recorder (musical instrument)|recorder]], viola, percussion, [[steel drum]] and backing vocals
*Jon Clarke – [[baritone saxophone]], [[English horn]], flute, tenor saxophone, soprano saxophone, bass saxophone, bass clarinet, [[Recorder (musical instrument)|recorder]], bass flute, oboe, [[steel drum]] and percussion (died in 2005)
*Larry Sims – bass and backing vocals (died in 2014)
*Merel Bregante – drums, percussion, [[timbales]] and backing vocals
*[[Milt Holland]] – percussion (died in 2005)
*[[Michael Omartian]] – keyboards, percussion and [[concertina]]
*Vince Denham – flute, bass clarinet, alto, soprano and tenor saxophone
*Don Roberts – clarinet, alto flute, alto, baritone, soprano and tenor saxophone
*Steve Forman – percussion, [[vibraphone|vibes]]
*[[David Paich]] – keyboards
*Dave Wallace – synthesizer
*Chris Brooks – [[koto (instrument)|koto]]
*[[Michel Rubini]] – keyboards
*Richard Greene &ndash; violin, mandolin, [[mandocello]]
*[[Rusty Young (musician)|Rusty Young]] – Dobro (died in 2021)
*Vince Charles – steel drums (died in 2001)
*[[Victor Feldman]] – percussion (died in 1987)
